Only confusion for me was where I can use the pass and not use the pass
Do it!. A cheap and enjoyable way to travel and see the sites. With so many options from short trips to day trips, this is a must do for Sydney.
Great transport system. The ferries in and around Sydney are a terrific and reliable form of transport and a must do for visitors young and old!!!

The only way to see the harbour. The true way to see the harbour, catch the ferry from darling harbour to the quay , hope on a ferry to Watsons bay, have fish and chips on the beach , and off course catch the ferry to Manly
A must. Get a multi travel pass and use them as much as possible they are reliable and quick and travel all over Sydney harbour. Excellent means of transport.

Great way to get around. If our you are staying anywhere in central Sydney jumping on the ferries is a great way to get around. Be it to Paramatta or Mainly or to Cockatoo Island the ferries are used by locals and tourists alike. The main ferry terminal at Circular keys and the Rocks are impressive in their boat coordination and pumping vibe with people everywhere enjoying when the sun is out.Prices are fine.

Need tourist pass. Used lots of ferries on our recent trip. Costly exercise......... They need to do tourist family passes, as in the end it was hundreds of dollars spent to get around. Easy to get tickets and find where to board.

Cheap sightseeing adventure. The best way to see the Harbour is on it, and Sydney Ferries offers a cheap and cheerful way to achieve this. Travel all day on a variety of transport for $22 adult or $11 a child - best sightseeing tour ever!
Great service. Get a train, bus and ferry pass for the time you are in sydney. Catch a ferry to Darling Harbour, Manly, the Zoo, Luna park, I cant praise the Sydney ferry service enough...AMAZING.
great service. This service is fantastic, we had a wonderful time cruising around from Circular Quay to Manly to Darling Harbour to Luna Park to Parramatta.
Hop-on-Hop-off. Good value - with commentary - to do the harbour features but book early to avoid clumsy queuing, even with online documents.

Must do!. Riding a Sydney ferry is a must do! I prefer the Manly ferry, but I rode a number of them, and the view from the front of the boat is wonderful! This is one of those inexpensive "must do" items in Sydney! I love the ferry!
Sydney vacation. Had a lovely trip from Circular Quay to Darling Harbour, really easy to find our way around the wharves

Absolute must do. The ferries are a great way to explore the harbour and foreshores. They're clean, fast and fun. There are great walks at pretty much every place the ferry stops at along the harbour. e.g. if you catch the ferry to the zoo, there are the most lovely walks along the foreshore (you don't even need to visit the zoo).
lots of fun. A bit expensive but a great way to travel along the harbour, the kids even managed to look up from their nintendos.

Worth the ride!. We took a ferry from Circular Quay to Darling Harbour which is about a 20 minute journey. The outside seats got the best view, and we got to take some lovely shots of the Harbour Bridge and Opera House from afar. The ferry ride also takes you right underneath the bridge.

The cheapest "harbour cruise". There is nothing better in a water city like Sydney to jump in one of the ferries (pier 5 is the best) and let it to go around . Any where. The short and nice ride to Darling Harbour is the easiest .The long one to Parammata even better. You can spend a day or more plying all the routes.
A great way to see Sydney. Beautiful boats, great staff and amazing views of the harbour and surrounds form the boat.Can't say enough for their service and affordability, go the ferries.

Must do Sydney experience. All of the sights and experiences of Sydney I've always believed the best of them was simply to take the ferries at night from Darling Harbour under the bridge and into Circular Quay. Simply beautiful. Heck take them whenever and where ever you get the chance - lovely way to travel and see Sydney
Many!. OK, spend a few dollars.The Ferries are as great as the Seattle Ferries!The Ferries are freedom!!!

A great way to get around. The Sydney ferries provide you with multiple quite affordable ways to get around to Bondi beach, Manly beach, and other places, while giving you great views along the way. Decide where you want to go through their maps or the information center right across, and get going. I took it three times to different locations.

One of the best $5 a traveller can spend. Forget all the the expensive stuff, train to Circular Key, ferry to Darling Harbour or Manly, cannot think of a nicer trip for the price anywhere in the world.
The way to go!. You simply can't visit Sydney without taking a ferry. Very cheap and reliable transport that also provides many opportunities for great and memorable photos!

Very Helpful. Ferry hopped a bit with my bro when I visited Sydney. The ferries are real helpful to get to places that would've been far off by road. Plus they let you on from the small ferry stops even if you don't have a ticket and let you purchase one when you get off. The rain, dark clouds and grey light added to the thrill of the ferry rides that day!
Great. We took the ferry over to the zoo, it was a beautiful ride however because we went in may it was FREEEZZZINNGGGG
Great way to travel. Fun way to get from point to point. Mostly on time and very comfortable. Note: They do not run if the harbor is fogged in.
Good for the views.... The Sydney ferry is a fun ride to take while in the city. If only for the view alone...definitely worth it. But if you need to get places too...they're useful.

Best way to see the city. We took the ferry to Manly beach and back. This is a great way to see the waterway and get a better grasp of the landscape. The ferrry's are fast and frequent so no need to worry about missing one.

Enjoy Sydney at reasonable travel fares. If you are intending to visit Sydney, go to the website below to view/purchase your MyMulti tickets from City Rail. These tickets allow unlimited travel on buses, trains and ferries at discounted rates. You can also purchase the tickets at the airport when you arrive - one day, two days, three days, one week ....from September 2013 you will have to purchase a MyMulti2 or MyMulti3 to e.g. catch a train to Circular Quay, ride the ferries to Manly, Taronga Zoo, Rose Bay, Watsons Bay, etc, then take the bus or train to Town Hall or any other station on the City Rail metropolitan rail line. It is a wonderful relaxing way to see Sydney and you don't have to blow your budget or gasket to enjoy this beautiful city. Go to the Information Centres or kiosks to obtain brochures or assistance. See Sydney's beautiful harbour and environs - use the ferries, trains and buses to get around via the MyMulti Rail passes. Checkout this website www.cityrail.info or the weblink below and put in your own destination: http://www.cityrail.info/tickets/fare_calculator.htm

Sunday Family Funday - Only $2.50 unlimited rides. If you're visiting Sydney on a Sunday and have children with you, you should know what the locals know... each member of your family can buy an unlimited 'Family Funday Sunday' ticket that offers unlimited bus, train and ferry rides for the whole dayA Family Funday Sunday ticket will take you as far as Newcastle in the North, The Blue Mountains in the west and Wollongong in the south ( there's no 'east'...that's just ocean!!)Buy your tickets on any bus, train or ferry and please explore our lovely city! Enjoy!!

Nice view of the city skyline. Like to take the ferry from circular quay to darling harbour as that gives me the best of the Sydney CBD skyline. Unfortunately, from 1st September 2013, those who buy mymulti 1 can't take the ferry anymore, so it will cost more to get mymulti 2 instead of mymulti 1.

Underrated experience. Surprisingly few people in Sydney seem to know about the great value a ferry ride can be. Hope on for a few buck and take a ride around Sydney. The views are awesome and they are often very open and spacious. SAfe with plenty of room on board. Go up top for the ocean breeze. For the romantic couples out there, take the ferry around sunset, and sit up top. Really nice memorable experience :)

Nice way to get around the city!. This was one of the many ways to get around the city, my girlfriend and I thought it was a great way to get around - you could see the sights at every stop. It doesn't cost too much, and more importantly they were very very very punctual!

The ferries are great way to get around. The ferries are great way to get around and enjoy the beauty that Sydney has to offer. They are a little more expensive than getting on a train or bus but well worth it!
Ferry to the Taronga Zoo. Took the ferry to the Taronga Zoo. Kids loved it and it offered great views of the Harbour Bridge and the Opera house. Thoroughly enjoyed it!

EXCELLENT value for money..... My friends and I spent 1.5 hours on the ferries last weekend (June 2013) weather was pretty good for Winter and we spent the whole time on the above open deck. I think it was $29 for 1.5 hours.. Great visiting all the places and sight seeing.... The ferry was comfortable and the skipper etc friendly and checked to see if we were ok etc. Very easy to get too, in Circular Quay.
Great way to travel. The ferries offer regular services around the harbour area, at a reasonable price - and give outstanding views of this iconic city. Better than a taxi anyday!
Ferry ride Sydney harbour. Great way to see the harbour & all the sites around & got some beautiful photos worth a ride regards Nicole watts

Tray and do the Ferry Trip on a Stormy Day. There is nothing more Sydney than going to Manly on a stormy day - when the waves are rolling through Sydney Heads. Adds an extra dimension to the Ferry Trip - and the kids will love it. Manly area at the other end is an added bonus.

stupid tickets machine. This review is only for the tickets machine only.We try to buy the tickets, as there was a long queue for the ticketing counter, so we choose to buy from the machine.first, the machine can only purchase 1 ticket per transaction, so when 4 of us travelling and the ferry departing time was just a few mins away, we were slow down by this "1 ticket system"~second, there is no change from the machine, you have to prepare exact amount of money for each ticket. the price is $5.8, and we have 4 ppl, we need to prepare 4 x $5.8. even I try to put in $6 dun care about the change, the machine just cancelled the whole transaction......I just find it very disappointed for such a bad ticket system in such a big modern city which call SYDNEY~~~~

Nice Sunset. Enjoyed the calm ride to Manley and the sunset was gorgeous, Very roomy and lots of seating. Good value if you have a Seniors Card as it only costs $2.50 to hop on and off the Ferry, buses and trains all day in Sydney

Discover Sydney by ferry. The first thing we do in Sydney is to buy a 7 day ticket for bus, train and ferries. It´s the best and most affordable way to explore the town in a pleasant way. The ferries are very safe and reliable, excactly keeping the timetable. To go back from Manly to Circular Quai after sunset with the view on the CBD,Opera House and the Harbour Bridge - WOW ! Don´t miss that.
Good day out. With overseas guests take them on one or more of the ferries, either to Manly or Watsons Bay. Gives them a good look at the Harbour and the sights. Trip to the zoo is also good.
Broke down. so many people had to wait for an hr and a half than it broke down and than had to walk back and it took 2 hrs from circular quey to harbour it was horrible plus the toilet broke
Fun!. Took the ferry from Manley to Sydney and would recommend it. Not expensive and views of the water, harbor, sailboats etc was terrific. Schedule was flexible with many times to choose from

cheap thrills. If you want a cost effective way to have a harbour cruise this is it. Most people go over to Manly on the ferry which is OK. Have a walk around and then head back. I suggest a ferry from circular quay to Darling Harbour that way you can do a city walk/ ride and go under the bridge for a photo op then a beer at Darling Harbour before walking back to the city...
Fun and enjoyable trip. We took the ferry from Darling Harbour to Luna Park. Great views of the bridge. We sat outside but there is plenty of seating inside.
Clean service. The cost is reasonable and the service is efficient and the ferries are clean. It is a great way to cruise the harbour for photo opportunities by day or night.

Forget overpriced cruises - take the ferries!. I've been to Sydney many times and I always head straight to Circular Quary then take a ferry - it's the best way to experience Sydney Harbour. Ignore the booths and brochures promoting expensive cruises. The ferries are a fraction of the cost and give pretty much the same experience (unless you want a meal onboard, but I think it's much better to just enjoy the harbour and eat at one of Sydney's great restaurants).Here are my favourite routes:Mosman - you can get off at Cremorne Point, walk the easy and very beautiful path around Mosman Bay, have lunch if you like at the Rowers Club along the way, then catch a ferry back from Mosman Bay to Circ.Quay. A great option.Taronga Zoo - to cross the harbour and go to the amazing zoo (animals never have a better view than here!)Darling Harbour - it's not as special as Circ.Quay but worth a visit and the ferry trip is very scenic.Eastern Suburbs - to see or get off at glitzy but very pretty Double Bay and Rose Bay or to go to Watsons Bay (but suggest not eating at the well-known fish restaurant there as it's grossly overpriced and the food is very ordinary).Neutral Bay - a short round trip across the harbour and past the Prime Minister's residence.Manly - ferry travels the full length of the harbour and arrives at this ocean beach where there's plenty to see and do inc. a lovely oceanfront walk.The staff at the ticket offices are helpful if you're unsure and there are easy-to-follow timetables for all routes.Sydney ferries - love them!

Love the Manly Ferry. We had a great time travelling over to Manly for dinner. It was easy to get a ticket and there was plenty of space to sit either inside or outside during our trip. The ferry was clean and the only thing I noticed was that there was some graffiti.
time stops. when you take the wonderful ferry to Manly. what a view and what a small price to pay for such a setting. memorable

Just love them. Love them every trip - there is always something new to see. The harbour side residences are always a treat as are the PM's and governor Generals homes but in the past few days, there has been a special Sydney Festival - Vivid - with amazing design and lighting spectacles.The light shows around the waterfront of Circular Quay were amazing and looking at the changing lights of the Opera House from the ferry was worth every cent of the ferry price.

Sydney Ferries. The Sydney ferries are a great way to get around the city. The views from the water in Sydney are amazing. The ferries are punctual and efficient. We were in Sydney for 2 weeks and we purchased a MyMulti pass that allowed us to travel on the ferries, buses, light rail and trains for the week without having to buy a ticket each time. This is a cost effective way to go if you are here for more than a few days. Great ride!
Convenient to use, and a great way to get around.. They are not horribly expensive, but they are a great way to get out and see different angles and views of the city.
Easy way to get about the city. Love the ferry, so cheap and ideal way to get around the best spots in Sydney Harbour. Relax and take your camera, the views are great.

inexpensive and relaxed. We used it to get to Sydney CBD from Paramatta in the west. we avoided traffic, which is crazy in Sydney. it was inexpensive and quite relaxed. By the way the views from the ferry entering the city were AMAZING. Also there is free WIFI available on the ferry :) just a note :)
interesting. no trip to sydney would be complete without a ride on the manly ferrie , very inexpensive and an icon of sydney , great photo opportunities

Don't overlook the connecting bus services. Sydney's ferries have a long and colourful history. Before the harbour bridge opened in 1932, ferries were the main form of transport from the north shore to the city area. Circular Quay was the hub of the public transport system which once had one of the world's biggest tram systems.Today's ferry routes are all interesting in different ways.The main tourist trip is probably the Manly ferry. There is also the ride up the harbour and into the Parramatta River.Plus several of the "traditional" commuter routes including my favourite, Mosman.Many ferry terminals have connecting buses and it's possible to make some interesting "round trips".For seniors (from anywhere in Australia) the $2.50 "pensioner" day ticket is excellent value and allows unlimited riding on most public transport on a huge area around the greater Sydney area.Ferries are iconic to Sydney and should be on the agenda for any first time visitor.
excellent, frequent services. Easy way to get around. They left on time and staff were pleasant.A very convenient way to travel- easy access.

Delay for one Ferry, just jump on another :). We had a pass that allowed us to travel on all trains, trams, buses and ferries in Zone 1. We decided to take a ferry to Double Bay, but it was delayed and there ended up being so many people queuing for it, that we jumped on the ferry next to it and took a round trip past the prime minister's residence, it was a beautiful day and a lovely trip seeing the sights of Sydney from the water. Well worth it!

worth doing. I chose the afternoon tea trip right round the harbour. It was quite expensive but worth it for the amount of distance and places covered. The crew were helpful although the general tour commentary was rather banal. The tea was plentiful but rather too much cake. It has to be done! Great photo opportunities and the weather was fantastic that day too.

Fabulous Harbor Views and Dolphins!. I bought a multi-day pass for the ferries/bus/subways and am very thankful! After walking for hours exploring the central area of Sydney, a ferry ride was a wonderful way to relax and explore other Sydney spots not easily accessible e.g. Manly, Watson's Bay, Darling Harbor, Balmain, Olympic Park, etc. I usually chose to sit outside either in the front deck or the upper rear section in order to get the best views, but that depends upon the size of the ferry. To Manly, the ferry was large whereas to Watson Bay, it was much smaller and much less crowded. On one trip, we saw dolphins and the captain slowed down the boat so everyone could get a glimpse. That was a treat!The views of the Opera House and CBD can't be beat but as interesting were other neighborhoods along the way, e.g. Double Bay as well as the small tucked away beaches and rocky cliffs.Tip - buy the multi-day pass if you stay for more than a few days. I certainly got my money's worth!
In Syd it is a Must. Four musts in Syd visit the Opera house, Taronga Zoo, Harbour Bridge and a ferry ride to Manley for lunch

Great value for Seniors. We cruised the Parramatta River from Meadowbank to Circular Quay with several pick up stops along the way. Opulent and interesting harbourfront residences were seen close up, many with private boat launching and storage facilities. Then under the Sydney Harbour Bridge and in to Circular Quay.Coffee at the quay then another ferry to Manly, no stops along the way but a close up view of a large cruise ship as it was about to dock.Fish and chips on the sea wall then we did it all again in reverse.Our Seniors day tickets cost $2.50 each. How else can a couple explore Sydney's waterways for $5!

Fun way to see the Harbor. You can select any of several destinations. We chose one that was fairly far away and just stayed on the boat for the full out and back trip. Great views of the harbor, the bridge and the opera house, as well as downtown Sydney.

Punctual and a great way to get around. Enjoy a trip on the Ferries to Manly, Darling Harbour or a number of spots in the Sydney Harbour area. Buy a day pass to avoid paying for each trip. If you get on on Darling Harbour and off before you get to Circular Quay, the ride is free.

Great way to see Sydney. Buy a ticket that lasts you all day, wear your walking shoes and go exploring. Get off at various locations for a stroll and bite to eat. Cockatoo island, Manley and Circular Quay are all great locations. Don't miss out on seeing the harbour at night.

when vistiting sydney, travelling on a ferry is a must. we went from circular quay around to to darling harbour just for the heck of it, we could have walked but we thought we'd get the ferry there and then walk home. well worth it. first stop was lunar park and if we had more days there we would have gone back just for that. 4 more stops and then we were at darling harbour. great trip and fun for the kids too

One of the thing that u should do in Sydney. Buy MyMulti ticket & can have unlimited ride on Sydney ferry. Should try to take the ferry from Darling harbour to Circular Quay at night...u will see an amazing view of Opera house & the harbours

A great way to travel. Take a trip over to Manly and spend a few hours there especailly on a sunny day. We also took the ferry and did the big walk you get off at Woolwich, there is a great pub where you can have lunch and a few drinks, great outside area and the food was great.
Great transport. Always on time but a little expensive. It is just a great way to see the harbour and get to harbourside locations.

At night. Just do it.. World class nightime city view. Just get on a ferry at night. No destination important. Go out in the harbour and see all the lights and come back on another ferry. Or, croos the harbour and go to a restaurant or bar on the other side. THe local ferry;s are like buses for the poeple going to work or living in the city. They asre cheap- lots of times and destinations. In the day we went to Manly to have a swim and as an escape the city. At night we took a ride on the neaon lit harbour after dinner just to enjoy the view.

Ferries were a fun and convenient way to get around Sydney. The stopping ferries were great value - as included in the MyTicket scheme - and a great way to experience Sydney - though perhaps seen better days.The express boat from darling harbour to Circular Quay which goes once an hour or 2 hours - is superb if you can get it - especially if you're in a hurry! (Also included in the MyTicket plan by the way)

what a great service. these run out of sydney harbour and go in many different directions. it like catching a bus and they run so often and are very cheap. They are very large so plenty of room and the staff are very helpful

A Great Ride!. We did not buy the unlimited ride pass for all transportation and should have because riding the ferries was so much fun! We took the ferry to both Darling and Manly and the views and ride was so much fun that we rode again just to enjoy it! The ferries are on time and easy to use. The free tourist bus drops off and picks up right in front of the Quay.

Great Way to travel. The ferries are brillaint for tourists just wanting to go up river for a day trip. Went to Parramatta on Sunday, gorgeous day and a lovely boat ride. Only $2.50 for all day travel if you are over 60, and that includes all trains and buses. What a deal! At Parramatta there is a free bus to take you round. Go to the Leagues Club for a great meal and cheap as chips.
Magistic Lunch Cruise. Lovely boat cruise around Syney Harbour about 2 hours long including lunch buffet. Food was good , scenery very nice - round all the secluded bays etc.

make time for a ferry trip. The Sydney ferries criss- cross one of the most beautiful harbours in the world, and they only cost a few dollars for a round trip. Don't leave Sydney without travelling on at least one. The locals use them like buses.

Rivercat - the only way to travel. Best way to get from Parramatta Area to the City is by Rivercat. What could be better - sitting in the sun on our beautiful harbour watching the sights & someone else is driving! The staff are all very helpful & courteous. So relaxing and great value - you're bound to fall asleep on your return journey. Tip - If you are traveling to Darling Harbour or Circular Quay consider parking at Rydalmere or Olympic park - no parking fees at all & Olympic Park has more return services, especially late afternoon on the weekends.

Great service and value for money. We booked Captain Cook Cruises to Taronga Zoo. The service was great and the cruise was on scheduled. It is definitely value for money as we have the choice to hop on hop off in one of their stopovers.
Sydney Harbour. The ferries are a wonderful way to see Sydney Harbour. It's lovely to sit and relax and watch the scenery go by.

Best way to get around. We took the ferry to Darling Harbor one evening and to Manly Beach another. The Ferry rides offer free wifi and are reasonably priced plus you can't beat the view. You could pay more for entertainment but if you just need to get from point A to point B, take the Sydney Ferry.
Harbour Zig-Zag. The best way to see the Harbour and all free with your MyMulti Card. Visit Luna Park - Manly - Taronga Zoo or just ride to take a rest or to take photos.

Best part of Sydney. If there was one reason to move to Sydney it would be the ferries. I love them. What a wonderfully tranquil way to travel. And the views of the harbours of Circular Quay and Darling Harbour are terrific, best opera house views too

Fabulous way to see more of Sydney. The ferries are very easy to access and ferry information easily accessible online or at the wharf. Some of the ferries are a little aged but this doesn't take away from the pleasure of cruising the harbour in the ferry to get from A to B. Wonderful views of Sydney

Nice experience and nice view!. We took the free shuttle 555 to circular harbor and trying to figure out how to get to Cockle Bay. We saw that there is a ferry that goes to cockle bay so we took it. It was about 5pm and it was a nice evening. On the ferry, its a nice view of the Opera house and Sydney beach. We saw the Luna park as well... It a nice experience to enjoy the scenic evening view of Sydney. Do plan your trip to visit the ROCK followed by the ferry. We did not realised that the ROCK is just walking distance away, so the 1st day we went on the ferry to Cockle Bay and travel back to our hotel via walking from Cockle Bay. Then 2nd day we went back to circular bay again because we wanted to visit the ROCK.

Hop on and travel the harbour. To see the best on offer on Sydney harbour, just hop a ferry anywhere Nd sit back and enjoy the sun, smell of the sea and the views of bridge, opera house, and all the live on this busy harbour.

Mosman to City and back. Since we were living in Mosman on our holiday, it made sense to take the ferry - which takes just 20 minutes. The best way to do it is to buy a Travel Ten (or its equivalent), which is economical and handy. We used it at all times of day and night, and it was always on time! Congratulations!

Sunday Funday. Didnt know about the Sunday Funday for $2.50! Will def be catching ferry on Sundays more often! Ferry went from Double Bay to Circular Quay in like 15 minutes and it was magnicent on the harbour! Best way to travel around sydney
Great cheap way to see the harbour. Great way to see the harbor and go out to manly for the day, also stops at taronga zoo and luna park so it's a great day out in sydney.

Fun way for the Family to Sight See.. We have travelled on Sydney Ferries several times. Easily located. Main hub is Circular Queue. Fantastic destinations. Close to Circular Queue Train Station, The Overseas Passenger Terminal & The Opera House.

Great way to see the sights. Use the ferry it is a great way to get about Sydney. They have various deals for your tickets so have a idea of what you wish to see and buy a bulk ticket, you can save a fortune.

Best value in the city. Just buy a day pass and enjoy. The multi pass works on ferries trains and buses so get up early a take the first ferry going out of Circular Quay it really does not matter where it is going if you are on holiday and this is you first time on a Sydney Harbour Ferry just see where it takes you, stay if you like the look of the place or come back to Circular Quay and get a different route.

Great way to get around. Took the ferry out to Parramatta. 50 min. approx. Beautiful scenery on a nice summer day. Stops at all the warfs along the way. Good way to see the different areas surrounding Sydney from the water. Beautiful homes and boats to look at. A must do if you are thinking of travelling out west. Took the train back to the city.

Great ride. I can recommend using Ferries any time. It was such a joy to travel from Darling Harbour to Circular Quay. Always on time, with short wait between the rides I would always travel this way. Not expensive at all, but with million dollar views all the time.

A fun way to travel. Sydney has the ferries that travel throughout Sydney Harbour regularly and commute workers, tourists and visitirs all over various parts all day and late into the evening. It is an affordable and fun way to commute. I found their service extends beyond normal public transport methods and a very enjoyable way to travel.

Get a City Explorer pass. The ferries where frequent and punctual. The journeys where thoroughly pleasant and the best way of getting around Sydney harbours. I would recommend visitors purchase a City Explorer Ticket for 24 or 48 hours which also allows you to use the City Explorer tour bus. Very good value for money and student discounts available.

Parramatta and Watsons Bay - 2 great cruises. Both leave from Circular Quay. The one to Parramatta is an excellent way to see how the other half live. Get early to get a seat out the front.
The second cruise is a great way to get to the Watto Bay Hotel and see Sydney Harbour at it's finest!

Love travelling on the water. We spent a week travelling on trains and ferries while in Sydney and the ferries were a pleasant journey and easy to get around. Every time we come to Sydney we buy passes so we get to travel on the Ferries.

Great fide. Sydney Ferries, what a icon of the harbor, large ferries, small ferries and very fast ferries. There are just so many great rides you can go on. There's the really long trip up Parramatta River or over to Manly. With Sydney Harbor being so busy there is always something to see.

Excelent way to see the harbours. The ferries are great rides with reasonable prices. Skip the tourist tours, get a day ticket and take a few ferries, you can start with the one to manly beach, when you get back take the one to the darling Harbour for some other great views on the other side of the bridge.

Forget the tourist tours take a ferry. Forget those expensive tourist boat trips just take a ferry to Watsons bay , it will be even better and cost just a fraction of the price. You will not regrgret it, this is what those in the know do !

RIde and Enjoy the Views. What an inexpensive way to both get around and see the Sydney area from the water. DO IT.
Only caveat is to have a good guide book handy to help you know what's where and what you are seeing.

Sunday Funday. We were super impressed when we turned up at the ferry to catch it across to the Zoo to be told on Sunday we could get a "Funday" ticket and use it on the entire city rail, ferries and light rail - all for A$2.50 per person! They suggested we buy our Zoo ticket when we arrived at the Zoo, saving us about $A10 per person. Big thumbs up from us.

Buy a Day Pass!. Buy the public transportation Day Pass. It is well worth it... take the ferries, buses and trains to wherever they go, hop on - hop off, for a fun day of self-guided touring... all for one very low price.
Quick trip. Fastest way from CBD to zoo. Clean,comfortable and only 12 minutes on the water. Great views of Sydney Opera House.
Love the Ferries!. The ferries are an amazing way of travelling! We would always choose them over any other kind of transport.
Great. Clean, good value and punctual. A trip on a ferry is certainly a great way to get from A to B. They even have free Wifi in certain areas.

Water way to have a good time. I like the Sydney ferries. I've never been on one that didn't depart on time and the only 2 times it didn't arrive on time was when we had to wait for a cruise ship to be towed out of Sydney harbour, which is pretty cool to watch anyway. Sometimes you see fireworks across the harbour as you're approaching.There's a cafe on board as well as charge points for your phone and a filtered water fountain.The front and back sections fill up quickly so if you want to get a good view and take some pictures, try and get to the front of the queue.

lovely way to end our day. We ended a day tour on a ferry that went around the harbor and we really enjoyed it. A lot of locals as well as tourists seemed to be on board. Had fun watching the kids enjoy the view.

Sydney ferries. The ferry was very full as we used it on a Sunday (families ride for $2.50 all day!). It was a bit expensive to ride it one way across from Darling Harbor to Circular Quay because we did not have children! We were hurrying through the gates to catch it and they left just as we got to the gangway (they saw us coming, but still pulled the gangway almost out from under us). Consequently we had to wait for about 15 minutes for another one. It was typical for a ferry in that everyone rushed forward to get on first. Once on, we enjoyed the ride.

Ferry, ferry good.. Theses are terrific, get a weekly ticket ( about $45,)which allows you travel all over Sydney on all public transport. Spend all day on the ferries. From Circle you can go everywhere at 24 knots, to wonderful destinations, take a trip all 'round the harbour...it's super value. There are pamphlets for each trip at the various stations. tickets are got from machines, get the person in the booth to help you figure out how to use them. some trips take an hour, so take coffee and sandwiches. Just be sure you know what times the ferries are coming back at if you are going to a particular destination. Cockatoo Island, Watson Bay etc etc...otherwise you'll have a long walk!!

Zoo Ferry. We took the ferry to the Taronga Zoo, across the harbor from the Opera House. It was a quick 10 minute ride - very easy - and the ferry dropped us off a the foot of the entrance. It's a great way to see the zoo and great views of the Opera House on the way.

Clean Efficient a Great Way to Get Around. We used the ferry from Circular Quay to Zoo and back. It is a nice efficient way to get around. There is a combined ticket that gets you both the ferry ride and zoo admission for a roughly 10% discount per person. And, it offers some opportunities to see the Opera House from a completely different vantage point that you can get in most parts of Sydney.We were planning to get a multiple ride pass, but decided to just do the Hop On Hop Off bus instead on this trip.

Cruising the Harbour. You have to take a ferry or go on Captain Cook Cruises to go to the zoo (Tarongo) in Sydney. You can hop off and on at the different stops. It is a good way to see Sydney from the water.

Take Ferries over private cruise tours. I would Highly recommend them over paying for a harbor cruise.Get a multi pass and explore the entire harbor.They offer free wifi (up to 45 minutes or 30mb) twice a day.

Inexpensive way to get around.. The ferries are a great way to get around to the different attractions in Sydney. It is about $7.50 per person to ride a ferry, but you can purchase a multiple ride ticket too. They are constantly running and you can catch them all from the harbor next to the Opera House and next to the cruise port.
Very good service. Frequent, punctual and efficient. Short trips are expensive-if staying for a few days the weekly multi trip pass offers better value.
Must do to see Sydney from the waterside.. Pretty to see the Operahouse from the other side along with the Sydney Bridge. Take the regular ferry and enjoy the view.

Great view for cheap money. Sit with locals and tourists alike and enjoy a great view of the whole bay. Sit outside and get the camera out. It's clean, fast, cheap and gives you all the view you want.

Is this not the best way to travel in Syd!. There is no better way to travel around Syd than on the ferries.
Views are amazing and time just seems to slow down

The cheapest way to see Sydney Harbor. Awesome views and reasonable prices, compared to cruises. Free wireless internet is included. The cheapest travel is on Sundays with Family Funday Sunday ticket for a mere $2.50 which covers the whole Sydney Greater Metro area between Newcatstle, Nowra and Lithgow, including every form of public transport in between.

Who doesn't love a ferry?. As an inland resident I just love ferries. What a wonderful experience to have. We've travelled on all the routes just for the experience. Great sightings and views of Sydney and its different suburbs. Each approach of Central Quay is an excitement in itself. Just see all the visitors taking hundreds of photo's. what a travel advertisement for the city of Sydney.

GREAT WAY TO SEE THE CITY ON THE CHEAP. Very economical way to see the the city from the water. If you don't need the music, expensive meals, and overall high prices of the commercial tours then you can't beat the ferries.
Transportation. We found out that this was the best means of transportation. The ferries traveled 15-20 minutes to all the different destinations. Great view of the city.
Run on time and efficent service. Run on time and efficent service. We bought a week metro pass and they are good on the ferries too. Great way to tour the harbor for a cheap price.

Amazing architecture. The Opera House looks good from any angle you view it from - the bay, the Harbour Bridge, from Mrs MacQuarries point or the Royal Botanic Gardens. Good souvenir shop and plenty of local eateries nearby.

If you like Sydney Harbour.... ...then you must ride the ferries. We got a one month pass for all buses ferries and local trains, which was superb value. Manly, Watsons Bay, and Parramatta were the favourite trips.

cheap harbour cruising. Catch a ferry to anywhere and you get a different view of Sydney. My Favourite is the Manly trip but Watson's Bay trip is pretty good or you can catch the river cat up to Parramatta.

harbour delight. the ferry and rivercat are great ways to travel around Sydney areas.We took the rivercat from pParramatta to Circular Quay.. a pleasant sightseeing trip at a reasonable cost.You can sit out on deck on a good day and the ferry makes many stops  Best of all you go under the Harbour bridge with photp opps galoretry this for a relaxing day without the car .

Great way to see the city. Easy way to get anywhere and see everything on the way. You can buy passes that will let you ride unlimited for the period of the pass or buy single tickets. If you catch the ferry at one of the parameter locations, you pay after you ride. You need cash, chip based credit card, or credit card with a pin to get through the turnstiles. If you jump on at Circular Quay, you pay before you ride.

ONE OF THE WORLDS GREAT JOURNEYS. HOP ON A FERRY AT CIRCULAR KEY TO ANY OF THE PORTS.Each stop is meet by a locale bus to take you around the area or even do a circle tour and hop back on the next ferry. Don,t worry where you are heading it is all beautiful and they all head back to the key at some time . Just relax and enjoy the people and the views. If worried ask the staff they are wonderful.

captain cook cruises. took ferry to pinch gut, had A great day but ferries to take us back to circular quay only took 6 people when there was about 30 wanting to get on. waited 40 minutes to get on another one. bad end to a perfect day
Great way to Travel. We bought a week long, multi zone My Ferry Pass. If gets you on all the ferries, trains and buses. No need for a car.

Very reliable and very enjoyable. Starting from Circular Quay these ferries transport visitors and city dwellers to Manly, Watson Bay, Neutral Bay, Toronga Zoo, Darling Harbour and Mosman. They ferry across the scenic Sydney harbour and Parramatta river and are both State Government owned and privately owned. Their safety record is exemplary and except a fatal crash in March 2007 their record is spotless. They have very catchy names - Lady Herron, Lady Northcott, and also salutes a few outstanding Australian sportswomen like Evonne Goolagong (Tennis), Marjorie Jackson (Atheletics), Anet Sargente (Netball), Susie O'Neil, Nicole Livingston and Shane Gould (all swimming) and paraolympian Louise Sauvage! On a nice cloudless day the ferry trip is invariably enjoyable.

Easy to navigate, good service. Figuring out the Sydney ferries was really easy for any tourist! They were pretty reasonably priced and we enjoyed all of our trips on the boats, and thought the free wi-fi was a nice touch, although spotty at times.

Best way to get around for the money.. If you are anywhere near the water, forget the taxis. I will only use the ferries to go from Darling over to the Rocks and back. They are inexpensive, punctual, and give views that you would die for.

A very busy and efficient service. It was efficient and great fun ride better view than a taxi cab ride NO red lights or traffic jams, great view at night of the lights and the Zoo ferry what a way to arrive to a zoo a wonderful service very professional
A beautiful harbor ride. We took the Sydney ferries to Taranga Zoo and to Manly Beach. They provide convenient transportation as well as nice harbor tour.

Can't come to Sydney without the experience. The best way to get around the harbour, with plenty of drop of places to visit. can just sit on it and soak up the harbour. great way to get to the zoo as well!

One of the Best Experiences in Sydney. Sunny day, breeze blowing, tons of boating activity in Sydney's Harbour: everything from kayaks to cruise ships and thereo you are enjoying all of it from a Harbour ferry. The Harbour Bridge looms over you and the Opera House is unique beyond words. When the weather is too hot, jump on a ferry going anywhere and just ride around the harbour. Views and people-watching are outstanding. If you are staying outside the CBD, the Harbour ferries are the way to travel. Love them, love them, love them!

Relax and enjoy. Took a regular ferry up from Circular quay to Paramatta, an hour of pleasant sailing watching the world float great experience. Slightly odd that I was not allowed to buy a return ticket but two singles got me there and back so no real problem

Excellent and friendly service.. What a beautiful way to see both Harbour bridge and opera house. The journey on varying ferries gives a Magnificent overview of Sydney Harbour and surrounding water front properties. Staff were super friendly and helpful, in general my overview of the Australian people were very helpful, welcoming and super friendly. Must do when visiting Sydney.

easier than going the long way round. To any traveller I'd recommend the ferries to cross from one harbout point to another. Its easy, the staff are so very helpful - I guess they are used to us tourists doing dumb things every day so they make it very easy for us. Just a tip, have ready cash in case your cards arent accepted by their machines which are nanny-ish in that they dont accept cards without pins, only certain cards, no Amex cards and so on

We love the ferries. We buy the "mymulti" passes and ride the ferries every chance we get. We do not even have to be going anywhere. The whole harbor thing is very interesting to us. I suggest you go to Darling Harbor, or Cockatoo Island or one of the beaches. Just going under the bridge is exciting.Where else can you do this.

Great Ferries !. If you want to get out and about then Circular Quay is the place to go. This is where you can catch all the ferries to the different suburbs of Sydney. Buy a multi pass which gives greater value and valid on ferries, trains and buses.
Very nice transport in Sydney. We bought a weekly ticket for 44 A§ each and you can travel on every ferry for short and long distance. The ferries are always in time.

Cheap and comfortable. Travelling by ferry is a cheap and comfortable way to have scenic views of opera house,Harbour bridge and to reach darling harbour and Maritime museum etc.We have purchased all inclusive(Buses,Ferries,and metro and light trains) pass (Weekly(7)Days pass for 61 AU$ /per person for unlimited travel in all 3 zones including bluemountain train.

Woarld Leading Harbour but poor ferry services. Don't run to schedule; hard to buy tickets with poor customer service staff; costly; services cancelled without notice or explanation. Suggest Sydney Ferries send managers to Hong Kong and New York to see how it should be done!

Liesurely way to get around. Make up your own Sydney Harbour cruise. We are seniors and bought an unlimited travel Pensioner Excursion Ticket ($2.50) which gives you all day travel on trains, Light Rail, Buses and Ferries. You can get fabulous views of the Harbour Bridge, Opera House, and lots more.

A great way to travel in Sydney. The Sydney ferry service is very extensive and includes most ferries on the harbour with the exception of the Manly Fast Loop, so a public transport daily or weekly ticket can cover wherever you need to go on the harbour. Download the Trip View App to get the timetables for all the ferries, and plan your trip from wharf to wharf (it covers the trains and buses too!)

Good value. If spending a week in the CBS buy a week transport pass. We caught the ferry every day between the rocks and darling harbour. The ferries were always on time and the staff very professional helpful and polite.Caught the ferries to Manley and the zoo. Great way to see the harbour.

Great way to see the harbour.. I love going on the ferry on a nice day. You can go past the Opera House and get a great view ( and great photos) .Wharf 4 over to Watsons Bay is fantastic!! Watsons Bay has fabulous views and is a very cheap day out! The best thing to do in Sydney!

Sydney Ferries on a MyMulti Weekly Pass. If you're flying into Sydney for your first visit, consider buying a MyMulti weekly pass ($44AUD/7 Days/Zone 1) that includes all your ferry, subway, train, and bus travel within the zone of your choice. For an extra $20AUD, you can also add on a RT transfer from Kingsford-Smith Int'l airport to the downtown Sydney train loop (Central, Town Hall, St. James, Wynward, Circular Quay, etc.) that is in easy walking distance to many of the major hotels in that area. Check out this website for all the information you'll need to buy a CityRail pass that suits your needs. (http://www.cityrail.info/tickets/which/mymulti)When exiting customs, follow the signs above (go right to the end of the lobby) that will take you to an escalator down to the trains. A convenient CityRail ticket office sits at the bottom of the escalator where you can purchase your MyMulti Pass and airport transfers.With your pass, the Sydney Ferries will give you the best views of the city skyline and harbour - particularly the Manly Ferry that departs from Wharf 5 about every 30 minutes. Here's a good website for more ferry/timetable informaton - http://www.transport.nsw.gov.au/content/sydney-ferries.The Manly Ferry: the upper deck seating at the rear of the boat will give you the best views of Circular Quay and the Opera House as you depart the wharf. When returning to Sydney from Manly, I would suggest the upper deck boarding queue/ramp for best seating availability. And, in both directions, beware that the bay can become a bit rough as you pass by the harbour entrance, causing some wave splash (at times) at the bow of the boat that could potentially wet down unaware passengers and their cameras !!The Darling Harbour Ferry: is especially good for getting great photos of the Sydney Harbour bridge, especially as you pass underneath this impressive span. Check out the photo of the Sydney Opera House after you've passed underneath the bridge - a classic money shot. You'll eventually end up at the Aquarium Ferry Wharf next to the Sea Life Sydney Aquarium - but keep walking towards the IMAX theater until you find Paddy's Market http://www.paddysmarkets.com.au/). This "street market" is definitely a full afternoon endeavor - clothes/shoes/souvenir stands galore - and don't forget to take in the upper floors where you'll find several outlet stores and a food court.The Watson's Bay ferry: will take you to the South Head Heritage Trail - a short walk from the Watson's Bay Wharf that shouldn't be missed. Here's a great reference PDF - www.nationalparks.nsw.gov.au/~/.../south-head-map-pdf.ashx. There are also some great photos of downtown Sydney in the distance from the top of the hill or from the Doyles Restaurant wharf (a spendy dining experience that is well worth the price !!) And, if you have time, definitely check out the Taranga Zoo and Paramatta ferries - both providing their own unique views of Sydney Harbour life.I've found Sydney to be one of the best transportation cities in the world - easy in, easy around, easy out - and using the Sydney Ferries by way of the MyMulti Pass is one of the biggest reason why this is so - enjoy !!

Don't do the tourist thing!. You'll see just as much of the harbour from the Quay to Manly on the normal ferry as just about any tourist operator will show you, so don't throw your money away. You also get a visit to a beaut beachside suburb

The only way to travel and see the sights. Forget all the tourist trips and boats and get yourself a one day ferry pass to see the sights and travel the harbour. Went up to Olympic Oark inc a local bus trip, Watsons Bay and Luna Park all for Aus $22, 00 and could have done more,

What a Harbour. Fantastic day on the harbour with my husband. We took the ferry around and it was awesome out to Woolwich Pier Hotel for lunch. Ferry was on time and very clean!! The outdoor section was amazing, the weather had a lot to do with it!! Definitely do that again and again!

watch out. It is very nice to book a boat trip. We did this in the hop on hop of bus. Because it was a bit cheaper. But then you don't know which boattrip you had choosen. There are several possibilities. Go to the harbour and book the trip overthere.

Sydney Ferries are great!. We bought a $44 dollar 7 day ticket which we used on ferries,buses and certain trains. We stayed in Balmain and travelled into Sydney most days then taking a ferry to wherever we fancied. The choice and views from the ferry were excellent. Buses also were used to travel around the outer areas. For $44 this ticket represented tremendous value.

Surely Sydney's 3rd Iconic Feature. The Sydney Harbour ferries are used by thousands every day to go to and from work. We bought a weekly ticket for trains, ferries and busses and used the ferries much more than any other transport. The ferries nip along at a fair speed but speed is not the main attraction. You can enjoy a harbour cruise, check emails with the free wifi and get over to Circular Quay easily. We took ferries to Parramatta, Manly (which costs extra), and pretty much every stop in the harbour. The ferry stops are great starting and finishing points for a walk or a cycle. The green ferries are as much a special feature as the Opera House and the Harbour Bridge. Please keep then as old fashioned and inefficient as they are.

Quite a value to buy a weekly pass. For 44 dollars, you can ride all trains, buses and ferries for a week. A great value for all the transportation you need for New South Wales. Ferries run frequently and are clean and a smooth ride.

So much fun!!. I know the ferries serve a purpose -- to get people from point A to point B, BUT, they are also a great way of doing your own harbor tour and sightseeing. They buzz along with great efficiency and have WiFi, if needed. We LOVED them!!!
Right of time. Buy a day pass that will allow you jump on-jump off for all the ferries, boats, buses. Then, see Sydney from the water and the 'burbs on the buses/trains.

Cheaper than a Harbor Tour. Buy a ticket to the furthest point and enjoy the beaches and the scenic ride. If you get the "fast ferry" the whole trip is only about 50 minutes. Cost for 2 people is about $25 USD.

much cheaper than a boat trip`. If you like the boats and can afford the trips it is nice just to sit on here and watch the city go by. Its $5.80 for a single journey (make the most out of it) if you are using it regularly check out their weekly passes etc.

You get your money worth when you buy the 24 hr pass. One day we took the ferry to The Taronga Zoo, we just visited the Australia’s section to enjoy all the fascinating creatures. You take the Cable Car up to the top and walk your way down to the Ferry.

Great weekly deals. I bought a weekly ticket for all the ferries and the public transport and just loved the convenience of it. It was much cheaper than buying each ticket by itself and I got to explore so much more than I otherwise would have.
Great deal for visiting the city
Excellent. Brilliant service .get the special weekly passes .Which allow unlimited travel on buses,trains,and ferries.Great value for money.Hop on and off as much as you like.

Best way to explore the Sydney harbour. Don't go for lunch - take the "coffee Cruise" - it's simply great. You get the best view of Sydney harbour, including a guide who explains everything in details. And you also get a nice "coffee break". Although the atmosphere is rather like in MC Donalds, it still good value for money and the cookies were better than expected. Bear in mind you would spend the same amount for a lunch or so. Here you have both for the same price

Great service, on time, ok pricing (and Wi-Fi on-board!). Used Sydney ferries to reach the Taronga zoo and was impressed with them. Professional, punctual, well maintained boats, ok pricing ($11.6 for a return ticket, each way took 15').The best of it: Wi-Fi on the boat so you can browse your next destination on the way. Well done!(And no queues at the service desks where you get the tickets)
great. went by ferry to cockatoo island and the next day over to watsons bay. a great trip both times. what a beautiful harbour

Best way to see the Harbour. The ferry system remains one of the best ways to get around and enjoy the harbour. Tickets and the routes are easy to understand and pretty reasonable. I would recommend catching the ferry to Taronga Zoo as it is far less hassle and less expensive than fighting for carpark space. My daughter loves the ferry experience and looks forward to it every time. Pick your times outside major commuter traffic as it is a popular means for Sydney workers to get to and from business.

Easy to Get Around. Found the ferries to be easy to get around on. There was no payment station where we hopped on, Luna Park, but they were easy to work with when we arrived at Circular Quay. Just be careful about which way the ferry is going!
Great Experience. Travelling on any of the Sydney ferries is a great experience and is a must do for all tourists and locals who havent yet.

Best Tourist value in Sydney. Just buy a day pass and ride around on the ferries to look at the harbour, go up the Paramatta River, go over to Manly, up to watsons Bay, and in to the little coves of Neutral Bay and Mosman.Best day out you will have, and the cheapest
A great way to get around. I would recommend taking the ferry any where it goes. If you buy a pass, your fare is included and you'll enjoy amazing views instead of being underground on a train.

Sydney Ferrries. Ferries leave regularly and go to numerous places around Sydney Harbour. However I have only caught it to Manly Beach. This is a nice trip and good harbour views. My daughter catches the ferry to Abbortsford and from there to Parramatta.
Take lots of ferry rides!. A MyMulti trip pass for Au$22 gives you unlimited travel on ferries, buses and trains all over Sydney for the day. Well worth it!
A great way to travel. We took the ferry from Darling harbour under the bridge to Circular Quay. Very reasonably priced. Remember to have your camera with you for all the fantastic sights.

Family Funday. Very easy to use, clean with decent food and amenities as well. They are regular enough not to have to panic about missing one. My favourite thing about them - which none of the locals thought to tell me, was that on a Sunday you can by a Family Funday ticket at about $2.00 per person in the family and this ticket gives you all day travel on many public transport options.
great way to get around. Easy easy to use! Loved to use these ferries while in Sydney! Each journey became a cruise around the harbour and some of the places we visited were surpassed by the cruise!

A MyMulti ticket is a bargain. $22 inc tax. For that we sailed to the zoo, then later to Manly Beach for the best fish & chips outside Cardiff, and would have gone to Chinatown for dinner if the rain had held off. Don't mess around with tourist tours, the Sydney public transport system is great - use it, and contribute to the city!

Buy a week Pass. Get a weekly pass and make sure you take the Jet Cat to Parramata and drop in on Cockatoo Island.Even take the trip around to Darling Harbour and get the full benefit from this fabulous Harbour

Great way to get around. Great way to see the sights and explore other parts of Sydney. Easy to navigate and not expensive. You can check out the harbour, Manly, see the bridge, Luna park or even just take a wander around a harbour adjacent suburb and see how Sydneysiders live.

Quick, easy, clean and efficient!. All the ferries we rode were quick, easy, clean and efficient! Get the MyMulti Day pass so you have unlimited access to all the ferries plus the trains http://www.cityrail.info/tickets/which/mymulti_day

Cheap way to get all around the Harbor. It was fun just ferry hoping all over the harbor. we never had any problem riding the ferries all over the harbor and we even took the evening harbor cruise which although probably not as luxurious as the captn cook cruise all present had a good time! Well worth the money

Return trip around Darling Point. We did a return trip around Darling Point, it was a lovely sunny day and we were able to get all the photos of the Opera House and Harbour Bridge that visitors from the UK could want. Its a cheap and cheerful way to see the sites and its accessible to all, we had a mobility impaired person with us and they managed the ramps and all the staff were extremely helpful. We managed to do our trip just before the lunch rush, bear in mind these are commuter routes so can get very busy.

Amazing. Paid $22 to travel on trains, buses and ferries for the whole day. We went to Manly and then to the Zoo. Took the ferry back to Circular Key and then jumped on another ferry that took us up the Parramatta River and back. Amazing value for money and lots of room and good amenities on the ferry.
ShowBoat Ferry. We did the show boat. great fun, excellent food. Whole experience was affordable, and highly recommendable. staff were so helpful, cheerful and couldn't do enough. thank you.

A must when in Sydney. The ferries are a great way to get around Sydney. If you don't have anywhere to go, hop on a ferry anyway, just to get a different perspective on the harbour, for very little money.

Good service. Very efficient and reliable and you get to enjoy beautiful views. Saves you from going on cruises which are more expensive. The ferries arrive and depart on time but make sure you know the schedule.

Sydney ferries. Really good way of seeing a lot of Sydney and its suburbs. Using a day ticket is a cheap way to visit all parts of the Harbour and some of its bays and tributaries. It is easyto get on and off at any of the stops to do a bit of exploring

Hop on hop off ferries. We had the perfect day for hopping around Sydney Harbour. First stop was Fort Dennison for some history then back on the ferry to Watsons Bay for lunch. Running commentary all the way was interesting, fabulous views of the Opera House and Harbour Bridge. Several more stops including Darling Harbour, Luna Park and the zoo. Can recommend this for locals and tourists alike.

Not given enough destinations credits. I had researched more of the metro rail transportation than I did of the ferries, so when we used our "My Multi 1" ticket, I was surprised that we could of gotten to the destination just as easy or easier using the ferry! Nice to see the city from a different perspective.

Fun and relaxing for all. Staff have ways been friendly and helpful especailly when we've had a pram with us or needed extra assistance. A ferry ride is great for the young and young at heart!! You dont need a reason or anywhere in particular to go, just jump on, sit back and relax!
Ferry Free Wifi. In a country where free wifi is a challenge, the ferries have got it so right. 45 mins of free wifi twice a day. Perfect!

The #1 Tourist Attraction in Sydney IMHO. I lived in Sydney and commuted on the ferries in 1992-94. So on our return we took several ferries including Mosman, Manly, Paramatta, and Watson's Bay. The trips are still great, one gets a wonderful view of the harbor and environs, can sit outside or outside shady, and they're cheap.

Excellent Transport Option to see Sydney. The ferries make sightseeing in Sydney an easy option for travelling from place to place as well as enjoying the lovely harbour. They also provide excellent value for money for retirees, offering discounted tickets for offpeak periods during the day.

GREAT VALUE. We used the ferry service from Darling Harbour to Circular Quay purchasing the senior's day pass for a measly $2.50. For that, we could have travelled on the ferries, buses and trains all day long. What a bargain! I would have liked to have got on and off ferries for most of the day to see the sights - maybe next time.

Ferry ferry good!!. We spent a whole day travelling the length and breadth of Sydney Harbour and rivers on the Sydney Ferries. It cost $2.50 for a seniors excursion ticket . What a great way to explore the area. Circular Quay is a hive of activity and excitement and we travelled for about 4 hours up and down the waterways. We stopped off and had lunch on the Quay and then headed off for the afternoon. It was superb and very interesting. The iconic Manley ferry was a real treat with refreshments available on board and we were invited onto the bridge as guests of Captain Rex who gave us a very interesting account of the ferry system. I believe that the Harbour is one of the busiest in the world and it certainly appeared that way while we watched the harbour traffic in and out constantly during our time there.The staff on the ferries are helpful and friendly and the whole day was wonderful.

Fantastic value. Took the ferries all over the place and enjoyed every minute. The cruise boats are excellent too but the public ferries are much cheaper and tend to be less vulnerable to being jammed with tour group throngs.

Good way to spend a day. We got a day ticket ($22 I think) and spent the best part of a day seeing Sydney from the river. We went on the Manly ferry, the one to Watsons Bay and the one to Darling Harbour. A great way to see Sydney and rest your feet after a day of walking around Sydney.

The best way to see the harbour regardless of it being public transport!. The Sydney ferries service was just superb. We were in Sydney for the week (in balmain) so coughed up the $60 each for the travel pass which included the ferries, buses and trains making sure we got our money's worth. Why pay for a harbour cruise at over $100 each for a couple of hours when you can sit on these ferries all day and get to your destinations with ease. With free wifi and amazing views of the bridge and opera house what more could you want! We actually facetimed our family back in the UK so they could see the sights too :). Out door seating was great for when it was dry and sunny. Just one note these ferries do leave on time! But you get fit running for them ha.

Travel and site see at same time. Convenient and reasonable if you are a tourist to get from location to location.The bonus is the great views that you get all thrown in for the price.The most relaxing way to enjoy Sydney.

Buy a MyMulti Pass. Our shuttle bus driver from the Airport recommended that we buy a MyMulti pass & this was one of the best deals in Sydney. The pass costs $43/adult & gives you 7 days of unlimited government ferries, buses & trains (in the central area). We uses this so much & we were only there for 4 days.

Great Service. A great way to see more of Sydney as the ferries run non stop everything few minutes to all the outskirts of the city and the bays, so you get to see much more than from the roadsides. Good value for money too.

World's best harbour. Sydney Harbour is truly magnificent and the locals how to use it to the fullest extent. The ferries are fast, clean, run on time and have friendly and helpful staff. One must travel from the central hub of Circular Quay to Manly, to Taronga Park Zoo and up the Parramatta and Lane Cove rivers. Pick a bright sunny day and you will never forget the experience.

The best way to introduce yourself to Sydney. We often get a ferry from Rydalmere to Circular Quay and its the most amazing way to see the city.As you approach the city you see the Sydney skyline come into the horizon, then a butterfly in your tummy when you see the beige come into view. For first timers there really is no other way to introduce yourself to Sydney. As you get closer, pass the other harbours and the fantastic houses who are lucky enough to enjoy that view everyday. The ferry takes you under the bridge, so close you could almost touch it and just when you think it can't get any better, there in front of you is the opera house. It's just amazing! If you're lucky enough to catch a cruise ferry in the harbour that's fun to see too. This is a fantastic trip for anyone of any age. All his for about $16 for a return trip which you have to buy in two separate single tickets or a day rider which is more expensive, cheaper than a train or parking. It's cheaper if your an pensioner about $2.50 -fab!! The only thing I think it's missing is a tour guide. It's a fantastic opportunity to tell of the history of sydney as you pass so much on the way. Even if its just a recorded one that could be purchased in Addition, it's a commuter ferry so not everyone will want to hear by I'd definitely buy that.

Sydney Harbour Ferries. There are numerous ferries that ply the vast harbour. You can take a variety of tours to different areas, or use fast ferries to different destinations, such as the Taronga Park Zoo, or Manly Beach. You won't be disappointed. The views are wonderful, the prices reasonable, and the guides very knowledgeable.
Visitor to Sydney. My ferry left from Kings Street wharf and i got off in Drummoyne. It was on time, but old and not really clean. It got me where I wanted to go,.
I' jealous of the Sydney residents. The best views of the harbour are from the ferries. The residents see this every day going to and from work.
Double Bay Shopping. Great way to experience shopping in Double Bay is to travel by ferry and enjoy the beautiful scenery of the Harbour etc.

2 bucks to see Sydney. Great time and money saver to see the best part of sydney. Costs 2.50 for a day. There are weekend specials for families as well. The multipass allows you to see sydney by rad, rail and ferries. You can see most of Sydney CBD. Rides are available on a sexier version of the ferries called Rivercats.

Wonderful Experience. We rode the ferry to Manly and back on the ALL DAY Pensioner pass which cost $2.50.The scenery was fantastic, we got some really good shots of the Sydney Harbor Bridge and the Opera House.Our friend was a friend of the first mate so we were lucky enough to get to go where no other passenger is allowed, we even met the Captain and went on the bridge and was able to stear the ferry, a marvelous experience which i will never forget.
Get a MyMulti. The MyMulti ticket provides multiple ferry rides plus trains and buses, well worth the investment and the ability to easily travel and see more of Sydney's sights.

Getting around Sydney. Sydney Ferries - what an awesome way to travel around sydney and surrounding suburbs. Quick and reliable. Best of all Sunday unlimited travel for $2.50 per person. great if you want to see the sights by hopping on and off.Also another "freebie" for families is the Saturday night fireworks at Darling Harbour (over summer) spend the day at the park tehre too..

Sydney Ferries. FANTASTIC...Reasonable way to get about. Cheaper than the other watre ferries and water taxis. Try the Hop on Hop off ticket for $22. Get off and on at various atractions.Try going to Paramatta River and the Olympic Park...on sunny day it's a great way to get a tan !

Love The Sydney Ferries. While spending 12 of our precious 23 days in Australia in February/March, 2013, in Sydney, my wife and I used the ferry system a lot. We twice purchased weekly MyMulti tickets for ressonable charges, then rode the ferries (buses and trains as well for the same low charge), all week long.If you have never been on this ferry system, you are missing something. From Circular Quay (downtown Sydney), you can easily and often catch a ferry that will whisk you to grand locales within the harbour system, such as: Darling Harbour, Manly, Watson's Bay and Taronga Zoo. All were easy and fun rides. We enjoyed the ferry system and had no troubles, despite the severe physical limitations my wife has due to the ravages of illness. She walks in pain and has many weakened joints, yet we had no trouble as long as we took it easy and took our time. The ferry employees really look out for people and we found the other travelers to be mostly very understanding of the disabled.Thus, I rate the Sydney ferry system as world-class and worth every penny. Use it, and the buses and trains, to easily get around Sydney.

Sydney Ferries. With a 3 zone travel pass we used the Sydney transport to travel all over Sydney to Manley ,Bond I beach ,blue mountains on all transport everyone was so helpful with great customer service and getting off the buses it lovely to hear people thanking the drivers a fast transport system for visitors

Get a weekly ticket for unlimited use 40 dollars. The weekly ticket gives you unlimited use of all ferries buses and train meaning you can hop on to any ferry in the harbour and explore all f sydney available from the station at circular quay. Ferries go to some great bays and beaches inc Manly the best beach in sydney and also Balmain great for shopping. And watsons bay for perfect fish and chips
Really easy. Easy to use, a bus or a tramway: you are going on different coasts of Sydney easily without waiting and without stress
Take a ferry. Inexpensive way to have a Harbour Cruise. Free wi-fi on board Manly Ferries. Take the ferry to Manly, walk around the coast, then to Ben & Jerry's for an ice cream.

Best way to see Sydney. This is the best way to get around the Harbour and the least expensive. And of course you can have a look around the area of your drop of before geting the next ferry back to Circular Quay.

Best way to see Sydney. The Sydney Ferries offer a great way to travel about the city either as a form of transport or for sightseeing. The iconic trip is to Manly from Circular Quay and any visitor to Sydney should do this trip, get out at Manly for the beach cafes, walk to Shelly Beach and then return. But dont leave it there. There are many interesting ferry trips to be had, particularly up the river commencing with Darling Harbour and on towards Parramatta, the birthplace of the nation with lots of historic walks and buildings. They all seem to leave and arrive at Circular Quay so thats the place to go. The ferries provide a different perspective on the city and surrounds and perhaps a slightly slower, more gentile mode of travel.

Enjoyable. We took a ferry ride from Circular Quay to Watsons Bay and back. The service was very good, and we really enjoyed seeing the bays on the way. The service was punctual and the facilities were very comfortable. My only complaint was that as we returned to Circular Quay I stood up before the ferry stopped and when the ferry hit the wharf it really kicked me in the back. So, be warned, stay seated until the ferry really stops !

Not fancy but clean, quick, and good value. We took a ferry over to luna park and another one over to Manly Beach, which was a larger one for the longer ride that included a snack bar. Good views along the way of nice houses and sailboats. Good value as part of the multi-pass ticket that includes buses and light rail.
what a great day out. just doing the commute from manly to circular quay has to be one of the best in the world. and then go wherever you want in the bay by getting a day pass, excellant
Quick and easy to get around. Somewhat less congested than taking a bus or surface train.Calm trip,very little pitching, great harbour views and inexpensive.
they are a good transport sydtem. a modern fleet of boats that are timely and take you to any suburb along sydney harbour. they are not cheap but then again neither is sydney so go and enjoy the ride

Sydney ferries, for the full Sydney experience. The public transportation in Sydney works mainly by train and buss, it's really refreshing to take a boat to get a new approach on the city. The boats take you from one place to another with ease, or then just take a boat and travel to wherever it goes and come back. Amazing way to experience Sydney.We took the boat from Parramatta to the Circular Quay when we first came to the center and after that we used the boats when we headed off to Manly. Very comfortable, clean and nice. (And the Manly boat has a free Wi-Fi upstairs!) I think to experience Sydney is to experience the Sydney Ferries as well. :)

A great way to see the city. Just like the Star Ferry in Hong Kong, Sydney Ferries offer a great, in expensive way to explore the city with fantastic views. A must with every single visit to the city.

Great transport with an amazing view!. My little one loves the ferries - it is THE way to get to Taronga Zoo or Luna Park. Amazing view, lovely to travel on both day and night.If you are in Sydney on holiday for a week the best bet is to get a MyMulti Weekly Zone 1 (if you are sticking in the city), it gets you on all buses, trains and trams for a week and good value.

Quintessential Sydney. Sydney Ferries is the ideal way to get around. It is an joy to be on an early ferry crossing the Sydney Harbour. On many levels, it is a shame that Sydney doesn't take greater advantage of its waterways and get some cars off the roads.

$10 will let you see all this great harbour offers. The Ferry network is the best and cheapest way to get out on one of the worlds great waterways. From down town you can ride and hop off to directly visit the zoo, luna park (small theme park), beatiful beaches (Watsons Bay), shops at Double Bay and the many fine restaurants neighbouring the ferry stops (Mossman Rowers and Doyles to name a few).
Sunset tour. Afetr great day in the Blue Mountains took private ferry back into downtown, 2 blocks from our hotel. Accompanied by Chris Willis who provided eprsonal narration and fellowship.

Sydney. I bought the 7 day pass that allowed access to trains, buses, and ferries. Great value that allowed me to go way out side the city as well as all locations within the city. Beautiful city with a great mass transit system.

Try them all.. There are many trips you can take around the Harbour and beyond. Recommend travelling across to Milson's Point and back to Darling Harbour. There is a longer ride to Paramatta and if you like seafood, the trip over to Waton's Bay to eat at
Doyle's is a good outing. The ferries always run on time.

Buy the weekly pass.... Sydney transit system is comfortable, economical, and safe as the best way to "get around" the city. By buying a weekly pass ($60 USD), you can take all trains (even to the Blue Mountains), buses, and most importantly, the ferries. No waiting in lines, no calculations of zone changes. Just slip your card into the turnstile slots and board 24-hours every day. What a bargain!
Go everywhere. Great way to travel. We got a weekly ticket ($44) and went to all the bays. Frequent service and better than London Underground.

Great way to travel.. Took the ferry from Manley to Sydney and would recommend it. Not expensive and views of the water, harbor, sailboats etc was terrific. Schedule was flexible with many times to choose from. Arrives in a convenient site in Sydney, close to opera house, shopping and lots of hotels.
Great views!. The perfect way to see the harbor sites! The view of The Opera House and Harbor Bridge are sensational!

Greatest way to see Sydney- and low cost. Buy an all day ticket to see Sydneys waterways all the way from Watsons Bay & Manly in the east, Balmain and Milsons Pt mid way to Parramatta in the West.A great day out exploring Sydney.

very convenient. not only are the ferries convenient but the views are fabulous. circular quay to the zoo gives you a good view of the opera house and the best route to the zoo. circular quay to darling harbor lets you explore these two key sites. if your on one of the mult passes, the ferries are included, as well as buses. I recommend the weekly (multi1 - zone 1) even for 3 days or so.
fast and furious. these little Ferries are dodging about all over the place and make for a really fast and convenient way to get about.. well worth the money
Always refreshing. Cheap, cheerful and always much to see. Doesn't matter what route but the Manly ferry is tops. Stay outside and feel the breeze and spray!
Good service. Even if Sydney ferries are a bit expensive, the value for money is there.Well organized, friendly staff and very clean ferries.

Sydney Harbour at it's best. A great cheap way to see Sydney harbour at it's best. Very good for families or couples. There are a number of different routes to take like sydney to Manly, Watson's Bay or Middle Harbour.

Well Run and Well Maintained. Sydney ferries are reliable and enjoyable way to get around parts of the city. You can buy a public transport pass for the day and take ferries and trains and buses. Great deal if you are covering a lot of ground!

Ferry but not across the Mersey. What a brilliant well organsied ferry service, we thought that the piers were good, and the information excellent. Loved going on the ferries as we were in Darling Harbour so to get the ferry back there from a day out was lovely We did get on the wrong one once, and eded up going way down river but they didn't mind just

GOOD EXPERIENCE. The Sydney ferries are a great way to experience Sydney. There are so many waterways. The views from the water are magnificent. The ferries are an easy way to get around. I would suggest taking a ferry to the zoo or Manly. Do it on a Sunday and the cost is very cheap.
