Even if you don't have someplace to be, it's worth the price for the close-up photo opps!

Cheapest and best way to see the Harbour. Great, cheap way to see the Harbour from the ground. Loads of travel options with Sydney Ferries. Places that I thought you could only get there by train, you can actually get there by ferry.
Quick and easy. Travel on the ferries across the harbor and see Sydney from the water. Cheaper than a harbor boat trip and just as mush to see.

Easy transport. We got a weekly transport ticket which covered train, ferry, monorail, bus and light rail. Was the BEST way to get around the city. Cost $41 for adults and $19 for ALL the children. Ferries were a treat for the kids and had many routes and drop off points.

Use Circular Quay as your base for Sydney's best attractions and catch the ferry. We bought 4 x weekly Sydney bus, ferry, rail passes for our 5 day stay. We stayed in a privately owned Oaks Hydpe Park apartment which was a great location for sightseeing. Didn't like the dirty underground trains in the city, buses were great to get to Bondi, through the city to Circular Quay and ferries were fabulous to go Manley, Luna Park, Taronga Park Zoo and various spots around the harbour...Double Bay etc. Would have liked a later ferry to and form Watson's Bay during the week so we could grab a late lunch/early dinner at Doyle's takeaway fish and chips and walk to the Gap in daylight/twilight. It was fun to travel with locals, school kids and tourists alike on the ferries. If you use the travel passes they are good value, but took us a few days to work out how to make best use of them...next time!

Best cheap thrill in town!. Every time I go to Sydney I want to get a ferry somewhere, anywhere! One of the best is the one to Manly, especially when the sea is up - the ride across the heads is great (maybe not if you get seasick) I love it! Once in Manly have fish and chips on the beach then the ride back... you cannot get abetter look at the harbour. then there is the Parramatta Rivercat, or the lovely little trip to Mosman and the Zoo. And a trip on the Harbour at night is not to be missed!

A local way to see Sydney Harbour. I took this public ferry from Circular Quay to Taronga Zoo. It was a very scenic & local way to see the harbour. No commentary about the harbour and you just absorb the scenery as you sail across the waters. Found it very relaxing. There is also another ferry that takes you to Manly beach. Do try it yourself!
Scenic Transportation & Free Wi-Fi. Not only do you get to where you want to go with maximum scenery, but you can get free wi-fi while on board.
Best way to get around. This is the cheepest way to see and get around Sydney. Tip is not to miss a quick trip to Manly for a bite to eat!

only way to see sydney. every time i come to sydney my first stop is circular quay. i love travelling to various locations around the harbour on the old ferries as well as the newer cats and the monstrous manly ferries. truly makes the holiday.
What can you do?. The ferries are great, not always clean, not always exactly on time but beats swimming and you get a great view of Sydney

Essential. You need to get on a boat going into the harbour. The Manly Ferry is best for most people. It's also worth taking other ferries to get to know it more - buy a ferrry pass. You have to like it.

First thing to do after arrival. It allows to see the most important attractions in Sydney from a different perspective. You should also take another trip during and after sunset - amazing views guaranteed, especially illuminated Sydney Opera House, Harbor Bridge, Lunapark and a lot of skyscrapers!!!

A great way to see the harbour. Take the ferry to Manly as a cheaper alternative to a cruise. You still get the same great sights for much less.. if you are using a MyMulti public transport pass, this includes use of the Sydney Ferries so it's virtually free!If you are sitting facing away from Circular Quay, the Harbour Bridge will be on your left and the Opera House will be on your right. Doesn't matter which side you sit on as long as you sit on the same side on the way there and back (i.e. left on the way there and left on the way back) so that you get a different view.

The ferries make Sydney special. Forget the trains, tubes and buses, if you've a few days to discover Sydney, catch one of the ferries and delight in sailing to the many varied suburbs of Sydney. How lucky those Sydney commuters are, to sail to work each day!
Enjoyable way to see the bridge, harbour & Opera House.. even if the weather not great, this is worth doing.

Cute yellow and green vessels charging around the Harbour. If you want a great tour of Sydney's Harbour, just hop onto one of these cute green and yellow ferries. The ferries are named after the First Fleet and on Australia Day (26 January) there is a fantastic 'Ferrython' on the Harbour where the ferries don their Sunday best and race against each other across the Harbour - all in the name of Australian spirit and fun.I'd recommend taking the Darling Harbour ferry from Wharf 4 or 5 (check the board) and going back and forth from Circular Quay to Pyrmont Bay where you can hop off and take in some lunch or visit the museums in Darling Harbour.Another great ferry ride is the Circular Quay to Watsons Bay ferry. This takes around 25 minutes and upon arrival you'll be greeted by the smells of fish and chips at Doyles. You can walk up to The Gap and take in the roaring sea or walk along the Heads to the lighthouse.The other must-do ferry ride is the Manly Ferry which goes from Circular Quay. Get there early as it gets pretty busy and nab a great seat outside. If you want views of Sydney, sit on the right, for views of the Lower North Shore and the Zoo, sit on the left. This journey takes around 30 minutes.A cost effective way of taking the ferries is to purchase a MyFerry Ten Ticket, however, if you are doing a lot of travelling, it's better to purchase the MyMulti ticket which includes buses and trains. Bear in mind that the Manly Ferry is covered by a MyFerry2 ticket or a MyMulti1. Enjoy!I love the ferries and it's a great way to get around, I'm very lucky to live very near a ferry wharf so occasionally take the ferry to work; a fab way to start your day!
See the harbour. The best way to see Sydney Harbour is to take the ferries from Circular Quay to everywhere you want to go. It's cheep and the views are the best.
Certainly recommend. The ferries are just great. Purchase a multi one ticket for ferries, trains and buses as many times as you like in a week.

Definitely one of the cheapest and most interesting ways to see Sydney Harbour. It's probably true of all cities on the water, but the ferries really do take you do different places, and you see quite a different vista depending on whether you go up to Manly or over to the East or the West... and it's worth taking each trip. Because they are regular commuter ferries, some are included on trip passes, but also are fairly cheap to take. If you're going to Taronga Zoo, you really SHOULD take the ferry. Definitely a highlight. If you tend to mild seasickness, a lot of them are fine, but the ferry out to Manly can be a bit trickier.
take the Balmain ferry - a ten minute trip. different views to the Opera House and Bridge, and when you get there, a wonder of old houses and buildings, coffee and food venues, and funky clothes.
Cheap transport.. We travelled to and from Manly, cheap and a lovely way to travel. No traffic, comfortable seats. Very relaxing
Very clean. We took the ferries to Manley and Bondi beach. The ferries were very clean and the beaches are a "must see" as they are beautiful.

Paramatta River Ferry and Manly Ferry. Lovely trip up the river, nothing much when you arrive, so took the same ferry back again. A completely different type of ferry for the trip to Manly. A inexpensive way to do a harbour cruise.

The best way to see Sydney Harbour. On a Sunday, when we need inspiration we take a jaunt around Sydney Harbour on the ferries - it's a great way to see the sights and we recommend it to visitors as a "must do experience". The staff are friendly and helpful.

Sydney Showboat. We hosted a dinner for our overseas visitors by booking the Sydney Showboat package which included a 3 course meal, spectaular 1 hour cabaret show and a very funny comedy show by Jack Black. It was a superb experience and our guest went back with the best memory of their trip.
Better than I thought. I liked the fact that I could stand up at the front while the ferry, really a largish boat, shuttled from place to place.

Good Service, Consistant, Reasonable Prices.. If you are traveling in Sydney definitely take a good look at the Ferries. They run on a very regular interval and prices are very reasonable. Depending on traffic (ie form downtown to Manley) the Ferries will be far more reasonable in price, a much better view, and much faster.
functional transport. functional transport, around sydney, wera sturdy shoes and dont go if you get sea sick easley.

Good service ran on time. We used the service to go to Manly and Taronga zoo and back from Cremone Point. All ran when they were supposed to however the Manly one was always very busy. Pick up one of the timetables and remember to get to the gate in good time.
Excellent way of seeing life in Sydney.. Travelled whenever and wherever possible by the Sydney Ferries. The Manley Ferry is my favourite boat journey anywhere in the world.

Great way to get around. Simply the best way to get around Sydney and its shore environs.
Safe , efficient service with marvellous views thrown in for free

The ferries are fantastic.. Use the ferries while you,re in Sydney. The transport passes include them as public transport and it,s just another special part of being in Sydney.
The Paramatta run is a goodie!
manly. Trip to Manly could recommend to every one.Dont miss it rain hail or shine

Ferries. Best advise I can offer is if you are planning to travel around the city to a bunch of popular sites is purchase the daily or weekly rail pass - this also allows you to use the Ferries.
ARRIVE early on the weekends because these ferry lines build up quickly.
Efficient. Efficient, timely, well priced. Would recommend purchasing a mymulti pass which includes ferries, trains, buses for a weekly price
excellant value for money. what a view of the harbour bridge and opera house from the ferry you must experience this !!

Very well run, on time and just a nice little trip. I come from Brisbane in Queensland and we have ferries but they are expensive and take too long sometimes, where as I found that they sydney ferries are fast, on time and just a nice little trip to enjoy

Nice and inexpensive. We took a ride back from the Olympic site ferry to Sydney Harbour, I think it was only 8 australian dollars per person. Very clean ferry, they sell sodas and beer, make sure you have cash for your ticket.

Iconic yellow and green ferries are quaint. A ferry ride to any of the harbor suburbs is well worth the time. You chug across the harbor and have an amazing view of the Sydney skyline. Its a sight to see, especially on a clear sunny day. The ferries re not so expensive, and you can choose from about 7 different destinations, from 20 minutes to 1 hour away. You can even choose Luna Park - a carnival setting, for a short ride and nostalgic destination.
Hop on Hop off Ferry. Very helpful staff who recommended where best to stop off and spend some time, i.e. Watsons Bay and Darling Harbour. In all, a very efficient service.
Great way to travel!. Really enjoyable trip from Darling Harbour to Circular Quay. No better way to see the Bridge and the Opera House
Great Service. For public transport the ferries do a wonderful job. Mind you being on the prettiest harbour in the world has a lot to do with it. I found the timetable very adequate.
Do it every day. All good,the best and cheapest way to see the harbor.If you have s senior car they have a deal for all day at $2.50
super easy accessibility!. Figuring out how to get tickets and board the ferries was super easy! Great trip to Manly!
Great way to travel around Sydney. Very relaxing way to travel around Sydney and see the sightsat the same time.
Ferries. Easy to locate and good information about next time for ferry.
One of my favorites. I so enjoy being on the water and these ferries allowed me to connect to places of interest with ease and wonderful views of Sydney on each crossing.
Transport to everywhere. Take the ferry, you will love the views! Take photos from the boat for pictures you will treasure forever!
Good Experience. It is a good experience for anyone who is visiting sydney, the only thing is that the ferries only appear once every half hour so if you reach at the wrong timing... WAIT.....

BUDGET HARBOUR CRUISE. Just get on and go. All ferries return to Circular Quay, so the return trip becomes a budget way to see Sydney Harbour. If you have a seniors card ( free for over 60's) it costs the lordly sum of $2 for the trip. Cheap at twice the price! You can spend the day cruising for peanuts.

A Sydney must do, but beware the holiday crowds. A great day trip for family and probably the best way to see the centre of Sydney harbour.
Just use caution in peak holiday seasons as the waits can be frustrating.

Harbour ferries. Great way to get around when the feet were tired. We found the people at the ticket desks helpful and patient. As with everything in Australia we found our Euro didnt buy us much though !

SYDNEY FERRIES - DOUBLE BAY AND ROSEBAY. It is worht catching a ferry to Double Bay and/or Rosebay which are before Watsons Bay. Between both places you have Red Leaf Pool, Blackburn Gardens and Duff Park which give exceptional views of the harbour bridge. A hidden secret unless you know the Eastern Suburbs a little. Red Leaf Pool is wonderful to swim in and it is right near the Blackburn gardens.
Take the Ferry to Manley. Fun, great views. Interesting people aboard too. Manley beach is OK, can have lunch, walk a bit and come back
Even includes WiFi. Amazing transportation system. Whether you are taking a ferry, train, bus or just walking - it is great.
Great Experience. Take a day trip to Manly , views are fantastic espically on way in to circular quay

Get a multi-ticket for the ferries!. During our rainy week in Sydney we spent a lot of time on the ferries, the rain did not stop our enjoyment of this great form of transport. We particularly enjoyed a trip up the Parramatta River (and the mangroves as you approach Parramatta). Take the time to check this one out!

Circular Quay to Manly. Easy to use and know which one to get on from Circular Quay. Return ticket price was $13.20 adult. Takes about 30 mins in totalGreat views of the harbour as you are leaving and re-entering
Fanatastic means of transport. A great way to see the waterways of Sydney and the Harbour

Sydney would not be the same without them. Took several trips up and down river to various locations including Taronga and Manly. Quite good value, speedy regular services. Ticket staff helpful, timetables and information good. Ferries very full but clean and efficient,an excellent way to travel.

One of my favourite things to do in Sydney. Get a $20 all day ticket and just cruise from ferry stop to ferry stop! It's the best way to see Sydney. Don't miss fish and chips at Manly, and try a journey upriver on a RiverCat.

Efficient was crowded form of public transport in Sydney. Caught the ferry to Manly on a Sunday afternoon.
Disliked the lining up to get on the ferry but liked the harbour view on both trips.
The ride was good value for money and the terminals were in handy locations at either end of our journey.

A relatively cheap way to see the Harbour and beaches. The ferries leaving from Circular Quay are well used and although the price is no longer as cheap for UK visitors due to the exchange rate, they still work out as a better bet than taking the Captain Cook cruises. The trip to Manly Beach is particularly good.

An easy and affordable way to get around and see the harbour. The New South Wales ferries, based out of Circular Quay, are easy to use and take you just about anywhere you can go along the shore. They are very clean and efficient, even when busy.
Great way of transportation. free wi-fi on the second deck, and beautiful views. Good service and it takes you all over Sydney

Bargain day on sundays!. Great to find out by the ticket staff that it was only $2.50 for the whole day on ferries, buses, and trains for each person up to 4 people. So $10 got us around for the day. Great way to see Sydney.

Sydney viewed from the ferries. Views stunning.
Uncrowded
Quiet
Efficient
Value for money

Great way to see the harbour. We stayed at Darling Harbour and the ferries stop there and go to Circular Quay where you change to go elsewhere. We went to Manly to have a look around. The day we went was raining, so after walking around we went to the movies. When we came out, the rain had gone so we sailed back to Circular Quay. We were very happy with the feries. They are big enough so its not squashy, very clean and always on time. It is a very economical way to get around and you get great views of the Opera House and bridge.
Excellent. Great way to travel and see sites especially Manley.
Really good service. The ferries are great, and there are many to choose from. Very quick to get you round to the different harbours. Good availability.

Great way to see the Opera House and the "Coathanger". We took the Manley Ferry [pier 3] on a circular trip of the harbour. Buy tickets at Circular Quay, cost about A$13.50 pp return. If you want great views go upstairts and to the frnt where there are outdoor seats.

If you can do it by Ferry forget the rest. Can be tough in rough weather however travelling by ferry avoids the congestion that comes with large cities. It also takes you via the best parts of Sydney. On weekends I take my cycle complete with child seat and child and cruise to the best beaches, food and attractions in Sydney. The zoo, aquarium, Opera House, Botanic Gardens, Harbour Bridge are all on the ferry route as are Manly and Cronulla beaches.
Worth using for a trip around the harbour. A great way to get around but also worth a trip around the harbour to see the sights

Experience Sydney Harbour. On a sunny Sydney day, hop on a ferry to Watsons Bay. It's a cheap and cheerful way to enjoy the Sydney's beautiful sparkling harbour. When you get to Watsons Bay, grab some fish and chips by the water and soak in the view.
Fabulous Ferries. Fun, easy and cheap transportation all around the various harbors and inlets. Try an evening cruise for night photos. Go from Circular Quay to Darling Harbour for some great views.
Easy way to get around. Get the $20 all day pass that's good for ferries, bus, and trains. it's the cheapest way to get around Sydney.

Try it, why not. Most places I've visited where ferries are an option on the "to do" list, was because the ferries were a tourist attraction. In Sydney, it's a mode of transportation. Hop on a ferry from Circular Quay to Manly. It's a long enough ride that it allows you to enjoy the scenery and the fresh air and a fantastic view of the Opera House and the Harbour Bridge. It also drops you off at one of the most beautiful beaches in Sydney.On a different note: Taronga Zoo in Sydney is absolutely incredible! If you choose to check it out, make sure to take a ferry too!

take the ferry to view Sydney!. we bought the $20 myferry ticket which basically let's you ride the ferries all day. We took the ferry from Darling Harbour to Watson's Bay on our first day in Sydney and wow, what a great way to see the city!
Great timetable and fun ride. Went from Circular Quay to Watsons Bay for lunch at Doyles on the Beach. Fantastic, so fast and really great ferry ride.
Manly beach. Took the ferry over to Manly. A very busy place, great for lunch and people watching

Excellent value for money & great views. The trip from circular quay to Manly was terrific and on the larger ferries you also get free internet access. How good is that? Oh - the views are stunning too.
Great way to travel. This is a great way to get around Sydney and view this beautiful city

Top 10 must do list. The ferry system provides affordable mini-cruise style attraction to visitors if not other people. We took the Taronga Zoo ferry to the Zoo(15 min ride) and the Manly ferry to Manly Beach (30 min ride) on separate days. Both ferries depart from the Circular Quay. The latter shows scenic views of many Sydney waterfront suburbs and the outer harbor, including the cliffs guarding the ocean entrance to the harbor.The ferries are painted with 2-tone colors. Most ferries are small and look like cute toys. The ride is steady and comfy. There are seats inside and outside (bow, stern and both sides). On a sunny clear day, you may not want to disembark but keep on cruising!In my opinion, Sydney has the best scenic ferry routes in the world. I think it is operated more for sightseeing than commuting!
cheap way to see the Harbour. The ferries are cheap and easy to use. The best way to get around the Harbour, especially if going to the Northern beaches, take the ferry and the catch a city bus
Cheap Ferries. The Ferry Service is very cheap when you consider how over priced the rest of Sydney's activities are.
Take the ferry to Manly. For an evening walk on the headland and a quick dinner at the beachy but delicious The Pantry

Best way to see Sydney. Use the ferries to see Sydney from the water. These are not tourist ferries but public transport which go back and forth at regular times to all parts of of the harbour. try manly, or a trip to the zoo.
fun way to see the harbor. A fun way to travel around and see the harbor. Great views, plus you get where you need to be!
safe as always. Great experience... really enjoyable and they were running on time. Older style ferrys have more atmosphere to them but the new ones are very good...just a bit chilly sitting outside

Go to parramatta. Take the parramatta express riverboat from circular quay. It takes about an hour. The views from the river are great. Very leisurely way to travel. When you reach parramatta there is a free city shuttle bus. It takes you around the city and you can hop on and off. Return by bus, train or riverboat.

Punctual, clean and scenic. These ferries provide a great way to see Sydney, particularly iof you buy a $20 adult MyMulti day pass that also allows unlimited trips on Sydney's CityRail network (as far as newcastle, the Ble Mountains and the South Coast among other destinations), buses and the sole Sydney light rail (tram).The ferries are clean and comfortable, although queues for the Manly ferry can be significant in warmer weather.Do some of the quieter trips such as to South Mosman offpeak to see the 'real' Sydney harbour. Then walk to Siruis Cove and to Traonga Zoo, rejoining a ferry back to Circular Quay.

Efficient and Fun. Ferries ran on time and enabled us to get to other locations very quickly while catching amazing views of the Harbour. People rave about the Star Ferry in Hong Kong but the Sydney ferries were MUCH better!
Enjoyable, clean rides. Great way to get around and see the harbour. Ferries are clean and comfortable. Leave frequently.
Another must do in Sydney. Even if you just catch one ferry, you really should catch one!

Manly Ferry. A beautiful spring Sat. so the ferry was packed but this ride provides a gorgeous view of the bridge, opera house and the harbor. And Manly was full of beach goers, surfers, tourists, locals.....a great place to walk and then grab a bite to eat at one of the many cafes along the beach drive.
Great value if you are a senior. On time and comfortable sailing made this mode of transport our prefered one to get about the Sydney area.
Easy, cheap, fun. There was never a long wait when we wanted to travel to or from Taronga Zoo.
prompt! free internet!. we enjoyed all our rides on the ferries. the public ones had free internet =) there are a lot of choices of ferries and they're all about $6-12 per ride.
Go to Manley. We took the ferrie to Manley. A great trip from the city. You can have good fish and chips at the beach

Best way to see the harbour. Several ferries leave from the wharf - and you will find each station has several pamphlets to each destination so you can choose where you want to go. If you are short on time, station 5 has the ferry to Circular quay - get off there and explore the Opera house, then jump back on the ferry as the sunsets to get a spectacular view of the harbour and city!
Catch the Manly Ferry for best value views of the Harbour. You cannot visit Sydney without a trip on the Manly Ferry.
Any ferry trip is brilliant!. Just get on the harbour and go anywhere..eg watsons bay, Many or the zoo..all fabulous!

Such a treat!. These beautiful boats that sail through this beautiful Harbour. I've been through the Harbour many times--including in very high winds and waves. What a wonderful experience. Kind, helpful, lovely people will help you on both ends.

Ferries and smiles!. We love the ferries to get around, you dont have to sit in traffic and you get a view of the harbour at the same time :) It's so easy to get around this way. Maybe think about a day pass to get on and off all day.
Great. What an amazing way to travell around Sydney using the ferry. Liked the free wifi too.
FUN FUN FUN. We took one of these over to the zoo to pet a Koala. Nice, smooth ride
on time. Had a very nice view of city on return trip from manley

Fares are a bit painful. I wish it were a little more reasonably priced and there were ways to get discount tickets. However the service is excellent and it is a great way to cruise across the harbour. You can keep going back and forwards as long as you don't exit the ferry docks.
Take the ferry. The ferry doesn't cost much and is a great way to see the harbour. I recommend you do it on your first day in Sydney and when the weather is good.

Great way to see Sydney and travel to Manly. If you have a few hours be sure to take the Sydney Ferries from Circular Quay. There are different ferries which go to different location. I went to Toranga Zoo and Manly by ferry. The price is affordable and the views of Sydney are impressive. I would suggest a day ferry to Manly and a return to Sydney in the evening... Seeing the Opera Hous lit up after dark is impressive.

Gorgeous. Truly fun to ride the ferries. The Harbour is gorgeous and you get great views of the Opera House, Bridge, the Quay, and Darling Harbour. Also went to the zoo. Sit on the top deck outside if weather will allow and enjoy the sun!

best way to get to Manly. The green-and-cream public transport ferries in Sydney are not quite as elegant as the privately-owned ones, but they have great character! Also they offer free wi-fi, which we found amazing. We travelled over to Manly in 35 minutes, with lovely views of Sydney Harbour en route.
good service. A regular, frequent service around the harbour and free wifi. The deal to the zoo was good value.

Do try them. The other reviews say it all - these ferries are great fun and an economic way of seeing the harbour. You don't have to get off at the other end just sit on board and enjoy the cruise. If the weather is at all choppy you will get wet sitting on deck. Obviously the ferries are at their busiest at peak commuting times.Try and figure out how the "pushmepullyou" boat design works!
Efficient. Well sign-posted, and good service, everything was on time and well utilised.
Ferry trip to Manley. great!!!. Very relaxing, Opera House amazing spectacle! Very busy waterfront! Great weather hot! Loads to do and see on the waterfront!
Simple. Easy and efficient way to get around Sydney. Ferry to Manly a must do and you can see why people move to Sydney

Hard to believe it's public transportation. It seems weird to say that a form of public transportation would be one of your favorite parts of visiting a city, but in the case of the Sydney ferries, it's true! The ferries are so easy to use: they run frequently, the schedules are clearly posted, and they run on-time. We used them to access Darling Harbour, Manly, Taronga Zoo, Watson's Bay, and neighborhoods along the river. Staff on-board was always helpful. Best of all, it's a completely pleasurable way to get from place-to-place -- you are sailing through Sydney Harbour, with gorgeous views of the Opera House, Harbour Bridge, and wonderful waterside homes and buildings of the city! These moments on the boats were some of our favorite Sydney memories.
They work!. Use the ferries to get around. We went to Manly Beach and Darling Harbour on the ferries. A fun and great way to get around.

Budget sight seeing but oh-so-Sydney :). Buy a day pass and explore the whole network. See all the big sights. We loved our trip to Mosman, lunch at Mosman Rowing Club, walk along the cliffs and see the amazing real estate up close. Ferries clean and so punctual!

A Great Deal. We sort of wanted to do a harbour cruise, but instead we followed other peoples advice and just decided to take the ferry over to Manly and back. We're glad we did. It was only $17 pp or so, and it's nothing fancy. It's just a ferry, part of the public transportation system. The wharfs on each end were clean and nice, and we got to to experience Manly, which we probably wouldn't have done otherwise. If you go to Manly in the morning from Circular Quay, and come back in the evening, you'll get better pictures (you won't be looking at the sun) if you sit facing the harbour bridge in the AM, and the other side of the boat in the afternoon.

A good way to spend an hour or two. Me and a mate were only in Sydney for the day. We caught a ferry to Watsons Bay which takes approx 30 mins each way and it gives you a good view of Sydney Harbour, The Opera House, The Harbour Bridge etc.Try and pick a nice day to do it as we sat on the top deck which is not covered and it was a bit chilly.A good way to spend a spare hour or so and it cost under $10 AUD.

The ferries are so much fun and a great way to see Sydney & surrounds!. This was only our second visit to Sydney together and we actually put aside one day to 'ride the ferries' and oh what fun it was. We had glorious weather and for $20 each for the whole day it is great value - this ticket also includes unlimited train and bus travel too!Firstly we went to Watsons Bay and loved looking at all the gorgeous homes lining the shores of our stops along the way - we also had the thrill of seeing the seaplanes land (next time!). The views of the Royal Botanical Gardens, and the Opera House were fabulous.Next we journeyed to Manly where we had lunch at one of the many great eateries in the area. We enjoyed a pleasant walk along the path/park above manly beach and enjoyed watching surfing lessons and the beautiful blue water and sky. Then we went on the ferry that goes all the way to Parramatta - what a great journey this was - under the Sydney Harbour Bridge, stop off at Luna Park, more lovely homes, historical sites, boats, other ferries, the list is really endless. It was getting dark as we arrived in Darling Harbour and the lights of the buildings were magical as was the changing sky.A really great way to see a lot of Sydney and enjoy the variety of ferries - so many of them are so cute!!!

Picture-perfect views. Why go on a more expensive harbour cruise when you can see the same views on a state-run ferry?We used the MyMulti pass for journeys on Sydney Ferries from Circular Quay to/from Manly (night trip) and to/from Watsons Bay (day trip). This is a fantastic and inexpensive way to enjoy splendid views of the iconic Sydney Opera House, the "Coathanger" (Harbour Bridge), the eastern suburbs for e.g. Vaucluse and the city skyline. Plus ... there were lots of sailboats out on a Saturday afternoon!

Perfect Way to See the Harbour! Go At Sunset!. We took the ferry to Manly an hour before sunset so we could spend a little time walking around once we got there. We never made it past the ice cream shop. Anyway, we took the ferry back right at sunset and came upon amazing views of the Opera House, Bridge and entire harbour. Yes, the ferry was packed but worth it!

Never tire of the views.. Sydney ferries are a must see if you're a visitor. I enjoy the ferry from Circular Quay to Manly. I see new things every trip. The return ferry is the best way to see the Sydney skyline. It takes 30 minutes each way, and runs throughout the day. If you have little time, you can take a ferry to Taronga Zoo and back, you get the great harbour views, 12 minutes each way! If you have more time, take the ferry to Parramatta. The express service takes just under one hour each way. If you combine the Manly and Parramatta ferries, you've seen the entire Harbour, and the river that feeds it! If you're doing both in one day, I suggest starting early, and going to Parramatta first. You can walk a few blocks, get a coffee, and take the ferry back to Sydney. Lunch in Circular Quay, or Manly. NIce cafes in both spots. Walk along Manly's beautiful beach. Stay in Manly until dark, the city lights from the ferry are outstanding. The rail and ferries in combination offer tourists a great way to see most of the city, and some of the best beaches, without the bother of hiring (and parking) a car.website... http://www.sydneyferries.info/

A new look at Sydney. We caught the river cat from Circular Quay to Parramatta - what a great trip. We know the harbour well, but have never ventured further west than Hunters Hill. Once you get into the Parramatta River the banks close in and you can imagine the early explorers going that way. Also there are some interesting reclamation and redevelopment sites along the way, plus some great little parks to remember for another time.

Don't leave Sydney without doing this!. Ferries are a convenient way to move around, with amazing views, and giving you lots of travel options.I'd recommend getting one of the public transportation passes to reduce your costs and simplify your journeys.We bought at MyMulti pass for 1 week, (there are a number of options, depending on where you want to reach by train). For $41 it gave us unlimited public bus, ferries and light rail (tram) travel, and train travel to a certain number of areas - which worked perfectly for us as tourists.As for the ferries - do at least take the ferry from Circular Quay to Manly - you will not regret it!

A must do in Sydney.. I was in complete awe of the august views from the Ferry. I enjoyed every minute of the cruise. Not only was it an opportunity to relax and take a break from the go, go, go sightseeing agenda but it was extremely beautiful views of the city, the Sydney Harbour Bridge, and the Opera House. In addition, this cruise gave a great opportunity to take pictures with a great backdrop of these great icons of Sydney. Lastly, it was a wonderful surprise to see whales and dolphins on our cruise!!! Do yourself a favor and take a ferry cruise during your stay in Sydney. You will not regret it.
A must in sydney. There is no better and other way to see Sydney and get to te many beaches along the way Going on time and usually the staff is very friendly Don’t miss the fun = take a ferry
great views. what great views, we did the harbour boats three times, bit rough but the views made up for it

Breathtaking views & convenient way to see all of the Harbour. We took a night ferry and we cruised the harbour~ was able to see Opera House, Luna Park, Darling Harbour & Sydney Harbour Bridge~ very romantic at night~ and the price is good~ I highy recommend taking the ferry during the day too~ take to Manly Beach and have lunch there~ come back and take in the spectacular view of the Opera House~

A Great way to see Sydney Harbour. We caught the ferry from Darling Harbour around to Circular Quay, you dont need a ticket to board the ferry, you will need one when you exit the ferry terminal at Circular Quay.Ticket Machines are available at the terminal and are easy to use, they are touch screen and you can use your credit or EFTpos cards. I found the the MyMulti Daily ticket the best value, for $20 per adult and just $10 for both the kids (on the one ticket) for an entire day on all the government run Ferries, Buses, Trains and Trams you just can' t beat it for value.Sydney Ferries are one of the best ways to see the Sydney Harbour Bridge and the Opera House, take the ferry to Manly Beach and you get to see a fair bit of the harbour including Sydney Heads, it takes about 30 minutes from Circular Quay to Manly. Food is available on the Manly Ferry and toilets are on each ferry service.

Best Public Transport in Sydney. Now temporarily residing in Sydney, I look forward to a nice sunny day when I can use my mymulti pass which allows me to get to destinations via the water such as to Balmain, Kirribili, Parramatta and the most popular Manly.It is one of the most cost effective ways to travel with the pass as it pays for itself with ferry tickets and the views beat any from a bus and of course in the trains you do not get to see much if you're underground. For first timers the trip to Manly is a must to see the harbour and eastern suburbs by the ferry.
Excellent!!. Best way to get around from harbor to harbor. Fast, inexpensive and great value.

ON my 'must-do' list. I found the Sydney Ferries services really enjoyable, particularly those to Cremorne: more sedate than the Manly Ferry.Enjoy a walk through Australian flora at Cremorne coupled with stunning harbour views.

Can't beat the views and the price. Ferry to Manly from Circular QuayRather than spend money on an overpriced harbor cruise (usually with mediocre food), take the evening ferry round trip to Manly for wonderful dusk, twilight and nighttime views of the city.  Sit in the back on the way to Manly, then sit in the front on the way back from Manly to Circular Quay.  Note the ferry can be driven from both sides, so whichever way the ferry is pointing out from the dock is the "front" for that leg of the trip. Ferry to Watsons BayTake this ferry over and then walk around the coastal park The Gap on the opposite side of the ferry dock.  The views of the Pacific and the Harbor entry point are beautiful.  After this, consider a bus ride to Bondi or back to Circular Quay through the suburbs.

Amazign views, fairly priced and confortable. Perfect way of both travelling around Sydney and sightseeing. You can see all the views of the Opera House, the bridge as well as take pictures from the deck outside. We got a one week MultiMy zone one pass that includes all Ferrys as well as buses and many of the trains for $41. It was great value as just taking ferries to Manly and Watson Bay would have cost over $20.

Great way to see Sydney harbour. Take the ferry from Circular Quay to Manly. Stand on deck and make sure you get some photos of the skyline/harbour bridge/the opera house!
The ferries are chep to use and Circular Quay is pretty well organized so it not to hrd to find the right terminal and ferry.

Really enjoyable. Ferries in sydney are great. they run from really early in the morning until really late.
We got a 3 day sydney pass - unlimited trains, ferries, HOHO bus, sydney buses & airport express.
We just jumped on a ferry and went somewhere different. Great views of the opera house, bridge and harbour.
DEFINATELY GO ON THE MANLY FERRY!!

Best way to use public transport. The Ferries are def. the best way for tourist to get around, at least where possible. Not only are they a convenient way to get to places, you also get a cheap cruise with great views from the water at the different parts of the city. I overall took four different ferries, and I didnt regret taking one. As the other public transport (subway and bus) is not great in Sydney, the ferries really make it special. I bought a weeks pass for ferries, train, bus and I didnt regret it.

Cheap, and you get to see all the sights. I was in Sydney recently with my daughter and we bought a Family Funday Sunday Pass which cost $5 for both of us. This allowed us to use the whole public transport system all day.We rode the Rivercat from Paramatta to Circular Quay and it was completely full. As it was a hot day it was really wam (no air conditioning). The trip is pleasant enough and the view has its moments as you travel through the back of some industrial areas. Get there early enough as they will not overload the boat and you could get left behind.From Circular Quay I can recommend the ferry that goes around to Darling Harbour, it is a nice ride, past the Opera House and under the Harbour Bridge. It's not the quickest way, but it is a nice trip.If you are not from Sydney, riding the ferries is a cheap and enjoyable experience. If you are staying in Sydney centre I would not recommend the RiverCat to Paramatta and back unless you need to go there for a reason. I do hear that the Manly return trip on the larger ferries is worth it too.Like the Hong Kong Ferries it is really a must do for the tourist.

A great transport system day or night. A great transport system, defiantly worth a day pass. A great way to see the city day or night. Can be very exciting or romantic. Make sure you know the path of each ferry or you might be one for a while. But that is not too bad because you see great views.

Wonderful. Maybe it helps that the weather was great - blue skies and warm - when I was there (supposedly this was winter!) but the ferries were a marvellous attraction in their own right. They are practical commuter transport on the routes they serve; and in my experience (6 trips) efficient, reliable, well-organised (good information provided about the many routes available from Circular Quay) and with some notably friendly staff.As a tourist, I was using them as much to enjoy cruising around the harbour and river as to go anywhere in particular. The varying views of the harbour (not just the Opera House and that Bridge) are terrific - you do need to be outside the cabin, preferably in the bow. I can recommend the trip to Watson's Bay - a few minutes walk brings you to the Gap and clifftop views over the open sea. I enjoyed going upriver to Paramatta too - it's not as scenic in any wow factor way but you do see a different, surprisingly quiet at times, part of Sydney (with some low-key heritage attractions). I got the train back just for a change of experience and scenery. Which leads to the point made by others that the best value way to use the ferries and local trains and buses is with a combined pass: I used a Daytripper ticket costing 17.40 Australian dollars in August 2009 .Personally, I much prefer this way of travelling (on "normal" services) to specialized trips for tourists - so much cheaper, more flexible and no commentary!(I was also impressed with Sydney's trains and buses - maybe it's because I live in the UK!)

Cheap transit - priceless views. We bought a family pass paying for both adults and first child, second child rode for free on all day transit pass. We took the ferry from Circular Quay to Manly Beach and the views are second to none. What a picturesque harbor. We found the ferries to be running frequently and the system was very easy to navigate. The seats were worn, but the ferry we were on was clean. Manly Beach is a great destination with beautiful seaside walkways and hundreds of beachfront restaurants. We were there on a Saturday so it was a lively scene with lots of families, dogs, bikes, and surfing school going on. We also took ferry to and from Darling Harbor - also beautiful scenery and frequent, easy to use public ferry. There are some fantastic photos to be taken from ferry with Sydney Opera House or Harbor Bridge

Down the tubes they go!. What is it about GOVERNMENT operated transportation? The MANAGERS (elected or otherwise) need to take a month long vacation in JAPAN to see how to operate PUBLIC transit! We bought a 7 day unilimited ferry pass and it was NOT worth it. Don't get suckered. They used to have 3 cruises per day, including 2 dinner cruises. Now, down to ONE mid-day "cruise." They had 1 lousy sandwich "selection" at the cafe... and most people were BYO food and BOOZE! Not a way to run a cruise! To make matters worse, the SLOW BOAT TO CHINA dropped off one of the crew at the "workyard" (an unscheduled, time wasting stop). It's far better to waste 20 minutes of 100 tourists time than to give 1 crewmember cab fare to the workyard. Plus, those tourists must have really enjoyed seeing that "SIGHT." Something is going downhill fast here. The FAST CAT to Manly has ceased to run... PERIOD! The remaining CAT to Palmaretta went SLOWLY and at the end of the river had to CREEP. It was a boring and stupid river excursion. Well, they are saving big bucks I guess by providing outdated and SLOW ferries... "NO WORRIES" about running a fast and reliable CAT! If you should get stuck on one of the state run ferries, check out how dirty and worn out the seats and carpets are. We took a good roll when a competing company went by and a dirty filthy mop fell down across the passageway. Of course, there was nobody to attend to it. You could see the PRIDE and excellent seamanship of the staff all summed up in that dirty filthy mop that they were possibly swabbing the decks with OCCASIONALLY! Best advice on the ferries... Use the buses instead if you need to get somewhere. If you want to tour the harbour or go to Manly, use a PRIVATE operator. And don't even think of using these ferries for a cruise. TAKE A PRIVATELY OPERATED DINNER CRUISE ("STEAM or SAIL!"). What a sad sad Ferry "System."

A must-see. The history of Sydney Ferries in the last few years may have been one of the occasional collision or other untoward incident, plus allegations of financial mismanagemnt, but visitors should think more positively.It is wonderful that Sydney has regular public transport on its stunning Harbour.Take a ferry to Cremorne, and walk along paths full of red, yellow or orange-flowered natives such as grevilleas. Marvel at the banksia plants named after botanist Sir Joseph Banks.Most of all, let your hair down as the ferries efficiently take you from one wharf to the next.A cornucopia of scenic delight.Enhance your experience by purchasing a Day Rover ticket, valid for unlimited trips on CityRail trains, Sydney buses and of course the ferries.

Enticing, interesting and varied. Sydney tourists can save many dollars by taking various public ferries around Sydney Harbour (operator is government owned Sydney Ferries) rather than paying for expensive and overpriced Captain Cooks' or similar private enterprise tours.Buy an A$16 multi-modal Day Rover from any railway station or ferry terminal and make as many trips as you wish in a day. You can travel to about 60km from the Sydney CBD though of course the ferries do not operate as far from Sydney's CBD as the trains or buses. There is an excellent walking tours brochure available from the Tourist Information stall near Circular Quay.The iconic trip is a return journey from Circular Quay to Manly, because in 30 minutes each way you can be subject to the swells from the mouth of Sydney Harbour. Occasionally these ferries are cancelled due to rough weather, but Manly as a destination is delightful with many short or longish walks possible, some involving a walk through parts of Sydney Harbour National Park.The Inner Harbour ferries trundle slowly from wharf to wharf such as Old Cremorne. This is a ritzy part of town (you'll see the Prime Minister's and Governor General's residences) and if you alight at one of the wharves, a walk along the Harbour is possible. Either return to Circular Quay by ferry or choose a bus terminus and travel back across the Sydney Harbour Bridge.On the southern shore, a visit to Watsons Bay is a special treat, with walks and lunch at Doyles a favourite.Lastly there is the slow Rivercats to Parramatta along the River of the latter city's name. This passes through many mangroves with the riverbanks at times playing host to unattractive industries, although redevelopment is occuring in some places. It is not difficult to return by CityRail train but the walk between the ferry and the railway station takes about 15 minutes for a reasonably fast walker.Don't forget the obligatory shot of your family or friends on board a ferry passing the Sydney Opera House!
